['Issue 512648: WebviewLoginTest.BackButton fails on Linux ChromiumOs', 'Failed in builds 6351, 6354 and 6357.

Note: schenney@ landed a fix to Webview in r339763 (which first ran in build 6355). I thought it fixed the issue but then got another failure in 6357 (so this neither caused nor fixed the issue).

http://build.chromium.org/p/chromium.chromiumos/builders/Linux%20ChromiumOS%20Tests%20%281%29/builds/6351', '']

['Issue 570547: flash_ec: Move board --> programmer association to board-level', 'To associate boards with flash_ec programming methods, we have big tables in util/flash_ec, ex:

BOARDS_STM32=(
        big
        blaze
        chell_pd
        discovery
...
)
BOARDS_STM32_PROG_EN=(
        plankton
)
...

This is inconvenient because we need to add our board to the proper table in flash_ec every time we add or remove a new board, and often times people forget.

How about we add a new variable like "PROGRAMMING_METHOD" to the board-level build.mk files? Then we can just source that file in flash_ec and remove all our tables. PROGRAMMING_METHOD will have to be defined for each new board, but it's "free" when creating board clones since we usually just copy an existing board folder.', '']

['Issue 96894: Get ninja build working on OS X', 'It's not all that useful since linking is by far the long pole, but I guess if you have compile errors you'd get faster feedback than with make. (In Xcode, you can just "compile this file"/cmd-k for that). I'm mostly filing this so that I can assign it to people who bug me about it.

If someone wants to work on this, the steps are roughly:

1.) Let ninja know if it's creating output for mac or linux
2.) Slightly tweak linker lines for mac (cf http://code.google.com/p/gyp/source/detail?r=941), with this most gyp tests should pass (tests in tests/mac won't), enable these tests
3.) Let ninja compile .m, .mm files (cf http://code.google.com/p/gyp/source/detail?r=942)
4.) Move the XcodeSettings class from the make generator into its own file, let the ninja generator use that for flavor=mac (cf http://code.google.com/p/gyp/source/detail?r=944) Now base should probably build.
5.) Move MacPrefixHeader out of the make generator and use it from ninja (will be slightly more involved than the XcodeSettings change). Now webcore_platform should build.
6.) Add support for bundles to ninja (cf gyp revisions 950-956). Now some typ tests in gyp/tests should start passing
7.) Export a bunch of env variables that Xcode exports while building (gyp rev 971 and others), probably sharing a bunch of code with the make generator again
8.) Add support for postbuilds (967, 1001). Now chrome should build, almost all (or even all) gyp tests should pass.

Maybe there will be some pain dealing with spaces in filenames, but it should be way less bad than it was in make.', '']

['Issue 516344: [telemetry] Proposal to use pooled standard deviation in results to get more accurate confidence intervals', "Consider the following scenario:

  | We use telemetry to measure memory usage. Suppose that we get the
  | following results for the 'memory_mmaps_native_heap_renderer'
  | metric:
  |
  |   http://en.m.wikipedia.org/:  20.0, 20.2, 20.4, 20.6, 20.8 MiB
  |   http://www.amazon.com/:       7.8,  7.9,  8.0,  8.1,  8.2 MiB
  |
  | The resulting means and confidence interval delta ratios will be:
  |
  |   http://en.m.wikipedia.org/:  20.4 MiB ± 1.92%
  |   http://www.amazon.com/:       8.0 MiB ± 2.45%
  |
  | These results can be considered to have relatively low noise.
  | However, the 'Summary' row will show the following:
  |
  |   Summary:  14.2 MiB ± 32.94%
  |
  | which incorrectly suggests that there was a lot of noise in the
  | measurements.

The problem in the example above is that the calculation of the summary
statistics assumes that all pages should return the same result for a
given metric. While this might apply to some metrics, it is definitely
not the case for memory.

Mathematically, the calculation assumes that all samples (from all
pages) come from one probability distribution with a single mean and
standard deviation:

  Samples:  [20.0, 20.2, 20.4, 20.6, 20.8, 7.8, 7.9, 8.0, 8.1, 8.2]
  Mean:  14.2
  Standard deviation:  6.54

What I think we want instead (at least in the case of memory) is to
assume that the samples come from multiple distributions with different
means, but equal standard deviation:

  Samples:  [20.0, 20.2, 20.4, 20.6, 20.8],
            [7.8, 7.9, 8.0, 8.1, 8.2]
  Means:  20.4,
          8.0
  Standard deviation:  0.25

This so-called sample pooled standard deviation (see
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pooled_variance) reflects the actual
noise in the measurements much better as we can see from the
corresponding confidence level delta ratio:

  Summary:  14.2 ± 1.28%

(Note that we also calculate a single mean of all samples in the end)", '']

['Issue 453306: CORS enabled XHR requests may fail to invalidly reused cached responses from a different origin', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/39.0.2171.99 Safari/537.36

Example URL:

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. Run a CORS service with the following requirements:
   1. Advertises caching (max-age, etag)
   2. Sets Access-Control-Allow-Origin in the response to the request Origin
   3. Sets the "Vary: Origin" header
2. Make XHR requests from origin1 to the service
3. Make XHR requests from origin2 to the service

What is the expected behavior?
Requests from origin1 should continue to succeed normally.

What went wrong?
Requests from origin1 pick up cached content from the responses to origin2. Even though Vary:Origin is set, the request from origin1 fails due to origin mismatch (the cached response has origin2).

Did this work before? N/A 

Chrome version: 39.0.2171.99  Channel: stable
OS Version: 
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 16.0 r0

I can confirm this bug with a small test-case, even in the presence of Vary:Origin header. I've attached a small program, run.js, which is a nodejs program starting 3 servers. One dummy CORS service (on :8009), and two client servers (on :8001 and :8002). The steps to reproduce the issue are as follows:

1. Run `node run.js` to launch the dummy CORS server and two html servers.
2. Open google chrome.
3. Clear the cache
4. Open http://localhost:8001
   1. This will start XHR CORS requests to our dummy service at http://localhost:8009
   2. The first hit should be a `200 ok`, subsequent hits will serve directly
      from cache (i.e. `200 ok (from cache)`).
5. Open a new tab at http://localhost:8002
   1. Observe that all requests for http://localhost:8009 respond with a
      `304 not modified`.
   2. Observe that the first tab now starts failing CORS requests because it
      is serving the cached response from tab 2, which contains a different
      Origin (`http://localhost:8002` even though the `Vary: Origin` header is set.

See screenshots client1.png and client12.png (attached) for the results. I've tested this on Firefox and Safari which do not have this issue. When serving directly from cache, chrome should not fail on a different Origin if Vary:Origin is set.', '']

['Issue 473850: Chrome hangs on copying/pasting text in a input field on Mac', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_10_2) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/41.0.2272.118 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. Open browser
2. Open google search
3. Input some text into search field
4. Copy it
5. Or, paste some text into search field

What is the expected behavior?

What went wrong?
It hangs 3-5 seconds when copying text to clipboard.

Did this work before? Yes about 2 months ago

Chrome version: 41.0.2272.118  Channel: stable
OS Version: OS X 10.10.2
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 17.0 r0

It seems to be not a matter of system preferences, chrome configuration and user profile.
I tried to reset chome.
I also tried from a guest account on my Mac.', '']

['Issue 41654: Security: Permanent Clipboard Hijack', 'From https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=27751
--------------------------------------------------
testcase
https://bug-27751-attachments.webkit.org/attachment.cgi?id=33592&t=FklgCEMJBM

Usually system clipboard access is restricted in clipboard events like "oncopy"
and "onpaste." However I found that you can set the system clipboard in any
context (e.g. a timer event). 

This can be achieved by adding an IFrame containing a text input element into
the document, and turning its design-mode / content-editable on. The
execCommand will then become available via the added IFrame document. So to
copy text to the system clipboard, you set the text input's value (in the
IFrame) to the text to be copied, then you select and focus the text input
control, and finally issue a execCommand("copy") on the IFrame.

I have attached a demo, this has an example with malicious intent: where it
hijacks the system clipboard by constantly setting its content to a malicious
URL. Extra efforts can be made to avoid scrolling issues when
focusing/selection the text input by using absolute floats.

I'm not sure if you would consider this a security hole or not. I have tested
it on Safari 3 (Windows and Mac) and Chrome 2 (in which it works).', '']

['Issue 198122: player_x11 hangs when using GLES and openmax', "Chrome OS Version  :  0.12.433
Chrome Version     :  12.0.742.20
Type of computer   :  arm machine

Please specify Area-* of the system to which this bug/feature applies.
Area-AudioVideo

What steps will reproduce the problem?
1. build player_x11 from chrome source with GLES support
2. try to play video with player_x11
3. observe hang for a few seconds followed by a crash

exact output is
[0506/120232:INFO:gles_video_renderer.cc(152) Initializing GLES Renderer...
Segmentation fault (core dumped)

we've also found that it works fine if GLES support is disabled

we will need player_x11 working with GLES for factory testing", '']

['Issue 299813: [CSS Shapes] add shape-margin support for image valued shapes', 'Migrated from WebKit Bugzilla: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=121619
Originally reported 2013-09-19 10:54 PST by Hans Muller (giles_joplin@yahoo.com).


Description:
Currently shape-margin is ignored for image valued shapes.


Blocks:
[http://wkb.ug/116348] NEW - [CSS Exclusions] Add support for shapes defined by an image and a threshold

Attachments:
2013-09-23 13:43 PST: Patch [https://bugs.webkit.org/attachment.cgi?id=212386&action=prettypatch]
2013-09-23 15:36 PST: Patch [https://bugs.webkit.org/attachment.cgi?id=212398&action=prettypatch]
2013-09-27 09:31 PST: Patch [https://bugs.webkit.org/attachment.cgi?id=212815&action=prettypatch]

Posted on 2013-09-23 13:43:04 PST by Hans Muller (giles_joplin@yahoo.com)

Created an attachment (id=212386) [https://bugs.webkit.org/attachment.cgi?id=212386] [details] [https://bugs.webkit.org/attachment.cgi?id=212386&action=edit]
Patch

Add support for computing the shape-margin boundary for a shape-outside whose value is an image. The current implementation is correct but suboptimal.

> Source/WebCore/ChangeLog:9
> +        value is an image. The current implementation is correct but suboptimal.

Is there a bug that will improve it? Why not just do the optimal version now :) ?

Is it correct to ignore the empty intervals inside the shape?

> Source/WebCore/rendering/shapes/RasterShape.cpp:56
> +    m_xIntercepts.resize(radius + 1);

I'm not sure if it is worth caching these values. And if you don't need the cache, then you don't really need the Generator class at all.

> Source/WebCore/rendering/shapes/RasterShape.cpp:87
> +    ASSERT(m_intervalLists[y].size() <= 1);

It seems like you are going to need more than one interval. Seems like ShapeInterval::uniteShapeIntervals does very similar things.

> Source/WebCore/rendering/shapes/RasterShape.cpp:233
> +        intervalGenerator.set(y, intervalsAtY[0].x1(), intervalsAtY.last().x2());

Isn't this going to ignore the intervals inside? Why are you not doing the traversal for each interval?

> Source/WebCore/rendering/shapes/RasterShape.cpp:234
> +        for (int marginY = marginY0; marginY <= marginY1; ++marginY)

You can generate all the intervals for one line and then use ShapeInterval::uniteShapeIntervals to unite it.

Comment #6
Posted on 2013-09-26 09:57:17 PST by Hans Muller (giles_joplin@yahoo.com)

(In reply to comment #5 [https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=121619#c5])
> (From update of attachment 212398 [https://bugs.webkit.org/attachment.cgi?id=212398] [details] [https://bugs.webkit.org/attachment.cgi?id=212398&action=edit] [details])
> View in context: https://bugs.webkit.org/attachment.cgi?id=212398&action=review
> 
> > Source/WebCore/ChangeLog:9
> > +        value is an image. The current implementation is correct but suboptimal.
> 
> Is there a bug that will improve it? Why not just do the optimal version now :) ?

Because I'd like to lock down the correct behavior before adding optimizations.  The performance of the current implementation is actually OK.

> Is it correct to ignore the empty intervals inside the shape?

Yes.

> 
> > Source/WebCore/rendering/shapes/RasterShape.cpp:56
> > +    m_xIntercepts.resize(radius + 1);
> 
> I'm not sure if it is worth caching these values. And if you don't need the cache, then you don't really need the Generator class at all.

This is not just a cache, although avoiding a sqrt()  per interval is worthwhile.  The other motivation for the Generator class is to factor out of the code that computes margin boundary for a single interval.

> 
> > Source/WebCore/rendering/shapes/RasterShape.cpp:87
> > +    ASSERT(m_intervalLists[y].size() <= 1);
> 
> It seems like you are going to need more than one interval. Seems like ShapeInterval::uniteShapeIntervals does very similar things.

Only one interval is needed - the outermost limits - because the margin boundary is for shape-outside.


> 
> > Source/WebCore/rendering/shapes/RasterShape.cpp:233
> > +        intervalGenerator.set(y, intervalsAtY[0].x1(), intervalsAtY.last().x2());
> 
> Isn't this going to ignore the intervals inside? Why are you not doing the traversal for each interval?

See above.

> 
> > Source/WebCore/rendering/shapes/RasterShape.cpp:234
> > +        for (int marginY = marginY0; marginY <= marginY1; ++marginY)
> 
> You can generate all the intervals for one line and then use ShapeInterval::uniteShapeIntervals to unite it.

See above.

Posted on 2013-09-26 10:14:28 PST by Alexandru Chiculita (achicu@adobe.com)

(In reply to comment #6 [https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=121619#c6])
> (In reply to comment #5 [https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=121619#c5])

> > 
> > Is there a bug that will improve it? Why not just do the optimal version now :) ?
> 
> Because I'd like to lock down the correct behavior before adding optimizations.  The performance of the current implementation is actually OK.
How different is the optimization going to be from the current code? Suboptimal means there is another algorithm that will do it with a better O() complexity. If you don't think there's one now, you may want to remove that phrase. 

Anyway, if you already have an optimization in mind for the current algorithm implementation, please add a tracking bug and reference it from the changelog. Make sure the bug reflects your thoughts.

> 
> > Is it correct to ignore the empty intervals inside the shape?
> 
> Yes.
It's correct for now, but just because we only support shape-outside on floats. Exclusions are not going to work with this implementation. I think the code would not be a lot more complicated if you did it right from the begining. Please make it work in that case too.

> 
> > 
> > > Source/WebCore/rendering/shapes/RasterShape.cpp:56
> > > +    m_xIntercepts.resize(radius + 1);
> > 
> > I'm not sure if it is worth caching these values. And if you don't need the cache, then you don't really need the Generator class at all.
> 
> This is not just a cache, although avoiding a sqrt()  per interval is worthwhile.  The other motivation for the Generator class is to factor out of the code that computes margin boundary for a single interval.
While the image size is not expected to be too large, making an arbitrary large vector based on a CSS value doesn't seem reasonable to me. You can just provide a large margin and crash the allocator.

> 
> > 
> > > Source/WebCore/rendering/shapes/RasterShape.cpp:87

> > 
> > It seems like you are going to need more than one interval. Seems like ShapeInterval::uniteShapeIntervals does very similar things.
> 
> Only one interval is needed - the outermost limits - because the margin boundary is for shape-outside.
See above.
> 
>

> > > +        intervalGenerator.set(y, intervalsAtY[0].x1(), intervalsAtY.last().x2());

> See above.
>

> > > +        for (int marginY = marginY0; marginY <= marginY1; ++marginY)
> > 
> > You can generate all the intervals for one line and then use ShapeInterval::uniteShapeIntervals to unite it.
> 
> See above.

Comment #8
Posted on 2013-09-27 09:27:10 PST by Hans Muller (giles_joplin@yahoo.com)

(In reply to comment #7 [https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=121619#c7])
> (In reply to comment #6 [https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=121619#c6])
> > (In reply to comment #5 [https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=121619#c5])
> > > (From update of attachment 212398 [https://bugs.webkit.org/attachment.cgi?id=212398] [details] [https://bugs.webkit.org/attachment.cgi?id=212398&action=edit] [details] [details] [details])
> > > View in context: https://bugs.webkit.org/attachment.cgi?id=212398&action=review
> > > 
> > > > Source/WebCore/ChangeLog:9
> > > > +        value is an image. The current implementation is correct but suboptimal.
> > > 
> > > Is there a bug that will improve it? Why not just do the optimal version now :) ?
> > 
> > Because I'd like to lock down the correct behavior before adding optimizations.  The performance of the current implementation is actually OK.
> How different is the optimization going to be from the current code? Suboptimal means there is another algorithm that will do it with a better O() complexity. If you don't think there's one now, you may want to remove that phrase. 
> 
> Anyway, if you already have an optimization in mind for the current algorithm implementation, please add a tracking bug and reference it from the changelog. Make sure the bug reflects your thoughts.

Since the point about "suboptimal" seems to be misleading, I've removed it.

> 
> > 
> > > Is it correct to ignore the empty intervals inside the shape?
> > 
> > Yes.
> It's correct for now, but just because we only support shape-outside on floats. Exclusions are not going to work with this implementation. I think the code would not be a lot more complicated if you did it right from the begining. Please make it work in that case too.

Even when we add support for exclusions this code will just become an important special case. It makes the cost of computing the margin boundary proportional to the number of  lines that contain above-threshold pixels, instead of that and the number of above-threshold intervals per line.

> > > > Source/WebCore/rendering/shapes/RasterShape.cpp:56
> > > > +    m_xIntercepts.resize(radius + 1);
> > > 
> > > I'm not sure if it is worth caching these values. And if you don't need the cache, then you don't really need the Generator class at all.
> > 
> > This is not just a cache, although avoiding a sqrt()  per interval is worthwhile.  The other motivation for the Generator class is to factor out of the code that computes margin boundary for a single interval.
> While the image size is not expected to be too large, making an arbitrary large vector based on a CSS value doesn't seem reasonable to me. You can just provide a large margin and crash the allocator.

I've changed the code to limit this value to the maximum width,height of the image.  Doing so doesn't affect the correctness of the implementation and it prevents the problem you've pointed out.

['Issue 568326: Cast needs support for protected playback of HLS SampleAES content', 'Cast devices need to be capable of protected playback of HLS Sample AES encrypted content. Such content is encrypted using AES-CBC with "pattern encryption". The keys and media need to be handled securely by a CDM. ISO is extending its Common Encryption standard (CENCv3) to cover this form of encryption. ISO has also extended its MPEG standard to allow CENC in transport streams (ISO 23001 Part 9). 

(These two extensions have not yet been integrated into EME, and also do not yet provide full compatibility with HLS SampleAES).

Specifically, we need to enhance the media pipeline to allow specification of the encryption mode and pattern. We also need to enhance the MPEG2 TS parser to allow inclusion of encryption metadata in the stream (largely according to the ISO 23001 Part 9) and to parse out the encrypted and cleartext portions of frames to identify the "subsamples". 

This will be done in two CLs. The first will simply replace the current "is_encrypted" boolean in the {Audio,Video}DecoderConfig classes with an EncryptionScheme object. The simple is_encrypted case will default to AES-CTR without a pattern.

The code changes in the second CL will mainly be #ifdef'ed so as to apply only to cast devices. This will include the changes mentioned above to to the MPEG2 TS parser. In the future when CENCv3 is fully standardized and integrated with ISO 23001 Part 9 and with EME, then we should consider removing the #ifdefs.', '']

['Issue 639760: Contradictions between ESSL and GLSL for invariant qualifier', 'ESSL 1.00:
Invariant qualifier is allowed on varying inputs in the fragment shader

ESSL 3.00:
Inputs cannot be declared invariant.

GLSL 4.50:
Only variables output from a shader can be candidates for invariance.

The contradiction makes conformance/glsl/bugs/invariant-does-not-leak-across-shaders.html and conformance/glsl/misc/shaders-with-invariance.html failed on Intel Mesa with Core profile, since ESSL 1.00 shaders are translated to GLSL 4.50 shaders. If I run chrome with egl context: --use-gl=egl, these two tests passed.', '']

['Issue 194304: Handle FileIO::{Read,Write,Query} in plugin process', 'PepperFileIOHost::SetLength now calls PluginDelegate::SetLength, which relays task to the browser from the renderer.\nThis IPC makes SetLength twice as slower as other similar function like Query.', '']

["Issue 703134: Don't copy non-translated strings into every locale .pak file", 'Related to not translating flag resources (bug 587272), we now have a good number of strings that are not translated. However, we see no size savings because we just copy the english string into each and every locale .pak file.

Options for fixing this:
1) Remove all non-translated strings from non-english pak files, and have them fallback to en-US.pak at runtime
2) Create a separate .pak file for non-translated strings. Use it at runtime as a fallback for strings not in the main locale .pak file
3) Put all non-translated strings into resources.pak, and use this as a fallback at runtime.

Note that the runtime logic for #3 already exists, although the comment suggests it currently happens only for tests:
https://cs.chromium.org/chromium/src/ui/base/resource/resource_bundle.cc?l=538', '']

["Issue 693484: [Chrome][M55][Android7.0] User can't open URL when more than 20 tabs are opened", "Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. Launch Chrome
2. Open 21 tabs
3. Type URL (ex, www.amazon.com) on 21th tab

What is the expected behavior?
URL (ex, www.amazon.com) should be opened.

What went wrong?
URL (ex, www.amazon.com) is not opened.

Did this work before? N/A 

Chrome version: 55.0.2883.91  Channel: stable
OS Version: 7.0
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 24.0 r0

The same issue was discussed in https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=429657 but the fix was not landed.
The root cause is Chrome relies on the system to kill the renderers way before reaching 20. For good or for bad, the system has a hard-coded limit of 8 background processes. But OEM can update the limit of background processes and for example, OEM updates it to 64 and system doesn't kill process.
So this change on the limit of background process is impacting to Chrome tab opening behavior.

And this is not reproducible on Nexus devices since the limit is 8.
But it is very common that OEMs increase limit for performance improvement.
So Chrome should not reply on system to kill process but kill process by itself.", '']

['Issue 437898: Custom source retrieval tool is needed to support secure source indexing', 'Source indexing (a Windows technology that retrieves the necessary source files from version control when debugging) currently uses cmd /c to run the necessary commands to retrieve source files. This makes it impossible to use the whitelisting in srcsrv.ini in a meaningful way. To make this more secure we need to create a single-purpose tool that can retrieve source files but do nothing else. This tool can be shipped in depot_tools and listed in the srcsrv.ini whitelist section so that it and nothing else will be run by the debuggers.

Currently Windows developers who want to use source indexing with Chrome either have to whitelist "cmd /c" or just allow everything to execute without warnings. Both options are insecure.

This would also be a good opportunity to optimize the layout of the source indexing information to reduce redundancy. Right now the srcsrv streams for chrome.pdb and chrome_child.pdb total ~12 MB due to duplicate mentions of the sha1 identifier and minimal use of macros to represent common paths.', '']

['Issue 697254: autoserv: stop using atfork + possibly delete paramiko host code', "autoserv has this whacky incanation near the top of it:

try:
    import atfork
    atfork.monkeypatch_os_fork_functions()
    import atfork.stdlib_fixer
    # Fix the Python standard library for threading+fork safety with its
    # internal locks.  http://code.google.com/p/python-atfork/
    import warnings
    warnings.filterwarnings('ignore', 'logging module already imported')
    atfork.stdlib_fixer.fix_logging_module()
except ImportError, e:
    from autotest_lib.client.common_lib import global_config
    if _CONFIG.get_config_value(
            'AUTOSERV', 'require_atfork_module', type=bool, default=False):
        print >>sys.stderr, 'Please run utils/build_externals.py'
        print e
        sys.exit(1)


The purposes of atfork are sort of mysterious, but it seems like it is intended to fix deadlocks that happen when you mix locks with *threads*. I think we have shunned python threads for development for several years, so not sure why we need this code (last touched in 2008). And this whacky behavior has caused at least 1 CQ failure in https://uberchromegw.corp.google.com/i/chromeos/builders/daisy_skate-paladin/builds/9142 due to bad interaction with another CL that set up some logging before atfork had a chance to attach.", '']

['Issue 406656: Refactor mac fullscreen.', 'I've got a CL coming down the pipes that is a major refactor of the mac fullscreen code. The explanation is too long for a CL description, so I'm posting it here:

The previous code was convoluted, poorly documentated, and more or less            
incomprehensible. I went through and renamed/redocumented all the methods to       
reflect their actual behavior. In the process, I determined that the behavior   
of the code had diverged from what the developers thought the code did.            
                                                                                   
The previously held belief was there there were several distinct fullscreen        
modes. Using old terminology, they are:                                            
- System fullscreen.                    
- Presentation Mode.
- HTML5 fullscreen.
- Flash fullscreen.
- Simplified fullscreen.
                                                
(See the new documentation in browser_window_controller.h for a more detailed   
explanation)                                                                       
The actual behavior after all of the repeated and convoluted logic was             
untangled:                                                                         
                                                                                   
There are 2 mechanisms for taking an NSWindow, full-sizing it, hiding the menu  
bar, etc. They are:                                                                
- AppKitFullscreen API                                                             
- The Chrome method 'enterImmersiveFullscreen'.                                    
                                                                                   
There were previously 2 mechanisms, almost entirely duplicate code, for sliding 
the omnibox & toolbar.                                                             
- PresentationModeController                                                       
- FullscreenModeController.                                                        
                                
Going through the previous idea of 5 distinct fullscreen modes:
- System fullscreen. Used AppKit Fullscreen API. Did not have a controller to slide toolbar/omnibox. (This is a bug.)
- Presentation Mode. Very ambiguous. This term usually meant: Used AppKit Fullscreen API, used PresentationModeController, although sometime it meant: used PresentationModeController with 'enterImmersiveFullscreen'.
- HTML5 fullscreen. Uses PresentationModeController. Sometimes uses AppKit Fullscreen API, sometimes ''enterImmersiveFullscreen'.
- Flash fullscreen. Uses 'enterImmersiveFullscreen'.
- Simplified fullscreen. Uses FullscreenModeController, Sometimes uses AppKit Fullscreen API, sometimes ''enterImmersiveFullscreen'.

According to the documentation and names of the methods, "Simplified fullscreen" was never supposed to use the AppKit Fullscreen API, and Presentation Mode was never supposed to use 'enterImmersiveFullscreen'.

In my refactor, I stopped using those old terminology, which contained poorly defined terms. There are two mechanisms for making an NSWindow fullscreen.
- "Immersive fullscreen"
- "AppKitFullscreen API"

There is one mechanism (PresentationModeController, requires a rename) to handle sliding/hiding of tab strip and omnibox.
- Show tab strip and omnibox (Previously used by System fullscreen)
- Show neither tab strip nor omnibox (Previously used by "Presentation Mode")
- Show the omnibox (Previously used by "simplified fullscreen").

All previous methods of invoking various styles of fullscreen now: Choose one of the two fullscreen mechanisms, and choose a sliding style.

Functionally, this fixed several bugs:
- Attempting to fullscreen HTML5 content with --enable-simplified-fullscreen caused UI problems.
- Omnibox/toolbar did not slide in "system fullscreen"

From a refactor standpoint:
- Deleted FullscreenModeController.
- External (outside of BWC) invocations of fullscreen mode are much simpler.
- Significant code reduction in BWC. There was an intense amount of duplicate logic, checking for "presentation_mode" (which had different meanings in different contexts), checking for the simplified fullscreen flag (tightly coupled, fragile logic) which was removed.
- Code in BWC_Private got moved around a bit, but there is minimal new logic.', '']

['Issue 660231: Simplify the baseline-resetting commands of run-webkit-tests.', "There are a few baseline-resetting options for run-webkit-tests:
 --reset-results
 --new-test-results
 --new-baseline

From Dirk in http://crrev.com/2456073002:

> You can run run-webkit-tests in a way such that it ignores what the existing baselines
> are and just generates new baselines. In that situation, there are three different options 
> for controlling where new baselines are put: --new-test-results which does what you say, 
> --new-baseline which writes to baseline_platform_dir(), and --reset-results, which
> overwrites the existing baseline used on the port, whereever it is found.

> The theory is that you might know whether the test results should produce one kind of
> result or another and can then put the new baselines in the right place.

> All of this long predates rebaseline-o-matic and rebaseline-cl. It's unclear to me which
> of these options are still being used. --new-baseline is probably the least commonly
> used, and it might be that only --reset-results is really useful. The reason that's useful
> is because lots of tests only have one generic baseline, and you can know you can safely
> just update it in your initial patch and not have to gather any platform-specific versions.

By removing one or two of these flags, we could probably simplify some code in webkitpy.", '']

['Issue 564578: Unify iOS PasswordForm parsing with other platforms', "Non-iOS platforms use components/autofill/content/renderer/password_form_conversion_utils.cc, which employs particular logic to learning which password fields are new-password and which are current-password. This includes respecting autocomplete current-password, new-password and username hints.

On iOS this is handled in PasswordController's getPasswordForm, which has different inference rules, and does not care about autocomplete attributes at all.

Once PasswordController is upstream, we should switch iOS to us the same procedure as other platforms.", '']

['Issue 134584: Dialogs based on ConstrainedWindowViews need a different look and feel.', 'See https://www.corp.google.com/~kenmoore/mocks/chromeos/Misc_2012/Dialogs/Markup2/dialogs_markup2g.html for desired look and feel.

Comments from ben@chromium.org:

Here are the things I think you need to accomplish before this can be turned on:
- correct window shape (border radius etc)
- correct window background
- correct fonts, etc.
- screenshots of every constrained window with this new treatment.
- I don't believe you can implement the shadow, the animations or the nice dimming using the infrastructure we have today. This will require the Aura transition currently being planned, so I don't think any of that is a requirement. The designers may want a stroke of some kind around the window then in lieu of the shadow.
- I think this change will require some changes to how constrained windows are parented. right now they're parented to the WebContentsView, but as you can see in the new mockup they overlap with the browser UI (for anti-spoofing purposes, we'll call these the "Ian Fette Pixels"). This implies these dialogs are parented to the browser frame. Since they should be tab modal, I do not want to see these dialogs parented to the desktop (i.e. they should be WS_CHILD windows of the browser frame).

I highly recommend pursuing this work behind a about:flags flag. My prediction is it will take several weeks to get everything to look "right" and in the interim we need to be shipping releases.', '']

['Issue 104955: Implement setting-level indicators for settings that are controlled by policy or extension in chrome://settings', "Currently, we show a yellow bar at the very top of the settings page to indicate that some settings might be disabled since they're under control of enterprise policy or an extension. This is not good UX, since the user cannot immediately see what settings are affected.

The idea is to move to a model where we put little indicator icons next to each setting if they're under control of an external entity. Clicking on the indicator will show a pop-up bubble the gives more information, e.g. what it is that affects the setting and contextual action. For extensions, it should contain a link that takes the user that the respective extension's options dialog. For recommended policy, we'd like to have a way to reset the option to the recommendation made by policy.

There are mocks for this available at http://goto.google.com/zbqhs (sorry, Googlers only, will post screenshots on this bug).", '']

['Issue 44205: Need more bits (64-bit Mac): don’t declare host_arch or target_arch in GYP', 'For the 64-bit Mac GYP/Xcode build, architecture selection is handled at a
different layer than on other platforms. The target architecture is chosen
in Xcode via build settings. There can be no knowledge of architecture at
GYP .xcodeproj generation time.

As a precursor to a full proper 64-bit build, host_arch and target_arch in
GYP need to be changed. Currently on the Mac, they’re set to “ia32”. This
should change to “mac” as a pseudo-architecture, and an indication that
something special is going on.

Some .gyp files will need to be adjusted to recognize the new host_arch. In
most cases, these adjustments will temporarily cause “mac” to be
interpreted identically to “ia32” until these components are made able to
build properly on the Mac in 64-bit mode.

One .gyp file that needs such an adjustment is v8.gyp, which lives outside
of the main Chromium repository. v8.gyp will actually be made Mac 64-bit
aware in bug v8:706. This bug depends on that one.', '']

['Issue 463275: Automatically sync servers to prod', 'Currently, push to prod involves these steps:
 1) Test ToT (or at least, test a candidate commit hash).
 2) Update the prod branch to point to the selected new hash.
 3) Deploy the change by running a script that contacts each
    server and asks it to sync and restart servers.

Step 3) should be automated:
 1) Some sort of regular processing (i.e. a cron job) should
    check whether the server is running the latest prod branch.
 2) When the server is found out of date, run the same automated
    processing we run now, but locally, rather than from ssh.

Rationale:
Recently, I ran the deploy step, but it failed because certain servers
were down.  In order to move forward, I bypassed the failed server
by running the deploy step only on the servers that were still up.
However, that left one server that was out-of-date once it was
repaired and rebooted, which required manually deploying one last
time.

This procedure was reasonable, but error prone.  The process should
be automatic, instead.', '']

['Issue 163618: EventResult should be set by function call on the event object, not return value from the handler function.', 'The effects of different event results can be dramatic and unexpected. I believe we should not make developers pick this every time they write a handler function. Instead we should just infer ER_UNHANDLED most of the time and provide an API call to change this - one to consume (prevent further propagation via ER_CONSUMED) and one to cancel the default behavior (ER_HANDLED).', '']

['Issue 429931: Chameleon: Make all Chameleon tests work on VGA interface', 'This bug keeps track on the status of making tests running continually on devices with VGA interface. Parrot is the pilot device.', '']

['Issue 553601: telemetry: "Must call StopMonitoringPower" error when some other error happens', 'Some measurements (e.g., tools/perf/measurements/media.py) do the following:

def DidNavigateToPage(self, page, tab):
 ...
  self._memory_metric.Start(page, tab)

def ValidateAndMeasurePage(self, page, tab, results):
  ...
  self._power_metric.Stop(page, tab)

However, if something fails in the middle, ValidateAndMeasurePage might not get called ant the Stop() never issued.
This causes the next Start() to fail with an exception:
AssertionError: Must call StopMonitoringPower()

which makes the build logs in case of failure extremely hard to interpret.
See for instance: https://build.chromium.org/p/chromium.perf/builders/Android%20One%20Perf%20%282%29/builds/666/steps/memory.top_7_stress/logs/stdio', '']

['Issue 689429: Consolidate //device/{power_save_blocker, wake_lock} inside Device Service', 'Once the Wake Lock Mojo interface is hosted by the Device Service and the only usage of //device/power_save_blocker is within the Wake Lock implementation, these two implementations should be consolidated into //services/device as the internal implementation of the Wake Lock Mojo interface. Concretely, both directories should move into //services/device/wake_lock, which should be made visible in GN only to //services/device.', '']

['Issue 605516: Make it easier to repro failures from V8 waterfalls', 'Complex cryptic infrastructure makes it hard for developers to reproduce failures found in CI or tryserver locally. This stems from:
- Compile on builders, test failures on testers
- Failures show up on swarming collect step, hard to reason how the test framework was started

Goals:
It should be easy to reason from the test failure how to compile and repro locally. As an alternative, it should be documented how to download the build product from swarming for repro.

Rerunning the tests should work by running a test directly or through the test framework with a filter and other optional parameters (e.g. rerun counts to make flakes more likely).', '']

['Issue 155574: Calculator app buttons have delay when used through touch display', "From Kuscher@chromium.org:

It somehow  feels that when I press down, the button has some latency to go to the pressed state.  It feels faster e.g. on the touch test site: http://www.rbyers.net/paint.html.

From rbyers@chromium.org:

Yes, there is a 150ms delay between touch-start (what you get in paint.html) and tap-down (what triggers css :active state including button presses, links changing color, etc.).  [...].  I've seen myself that it's very noticeable in the calculator app, but also elsewhere.

This delay is a tradeoff around scrolling.  We want to be able to start scrolling without potentially triggering changes in layout or having the compositor block on the webkit thread - i.e. we can't send the tapDown to webkit until we're prepared to block scrolling.  [...]

Now since calculator doesn't have any scrolling, an easy solution is to just add touchstart/touchend handlers to the buttons and have them apply the desired style...", '']

['Issue 244891: Minimize use of ENABLE_MANAGED_USERS defines', 'Currently there is a lot of code which uses #if defined(ENABLE_MANAGED_USERS). The defines should be removed, and instead stubs should be used for OS versions which are not supported (yet).', '']

['Issue 311308: Move basic printing support out of chrome/', 'Version: trunk revision 228917
OS: Windows, OS X and Linux

OVERVIEW

Third-party projects like Chromium Embedded Framework (CEF) that use the Content API would like to share basic printing support with Chrome. Basic printing support includes the system default print dialog but does not include print preview or related UI. This means moving basic printing support out of the chrome/ folder and into a shared location like content/ or components/. The basic printing implementation currently works like this:

A. Create a singleton PrintJobManager. This owns the printing queue among other things and is referenced internally by PrintViewManager[Base].
B. Call PrintViewManager::CreateForWebContents(web_contents) to register a new WebContents with the printing code (PrintViewManager uses WebContentsUserData).
C. Add PrintingMessageFilter in the browser process and PrintWebViewHelper in the render process to handle the IPC messages.
D. Printing availability is controlled via PrefService and prefs::kPrintingEnabled.
E. Call PrintViewManager::FromWebContents(web_contents)->PrintNow() to initiate basic printing. This currently shows the standard native print dialog.
F. Clean up by calling PrintJobManager::Shutdown(). This blocks until all pending print jobs have completed.


PROPOSAL

1. Move PrintJob[Manager|Worker], PrintViewManager, PrintWebViewHelper and related classes to content/ or components/. Factor out the dependencies on chrome objects (ProfileIOData and BrowserProcess) and print preview (PrintPreviewUI, PrintPreviewDialogController). Print preview and related UI can continue to live in chrome/.

2. Expose settings for enabling/disabling printing programmatically.

3. By default show the standard native print dialog. Optionally provide the ability to:

A. Implement a custom print dialog via a new callback delegate interface, or fully specify the print settings without showing a dialog.
B. Supply header and footer information on a per-page basis.

There are two possible ways to approach the new API:

1. Keep the current singleton-based approach with PrintJobManager that uses WebContentsUserData to track WebContents lifespan. Expose PrintJobManager, PrintViewManager, PrintingMessageFilter and PrintWebViewHelper as public interfaces. This approach would likely be most appropriate if the code moves to compontents/ instead of content/.

2. Couple the printing implementation more closely with WebContents. For example, introduce WebContents::Print() and WebContentsDelegate::CanPrint() methods and have WebContentsImpl access the Print* interfaces internally. A minimal number of new methods are added to the public interface.


IMPLEMENTATION DETAILS

The existing files that would need to be modified and/or relocated (based on the above trunk revision) are:

  chrome/browser/printing/print_dialog_gtk.cc
  chrome/browser/printing/print_dialog_gtk.h
  chrome/browser/printing/print_job.cc
  chrome/browser/printing/print_job.h
  chrome/browser/printing/print_job_manager.cc
  chrome/browser/printing/print_job_manager.h
  chrome/browser/printing/print_job_worker.cc
  chrome/browser/printing/print_job_worker.h
  chrome/browser/printing/print_job_worker_owner.h
  chrome/browser/printing/print_job_worker_owner.h
  chrome/browser/printing/print_view_manager.cc
  chrome/browser/printing/print_view_manager.h
  chrome/browser/printing/print_view_manager_base.cc
  chrome/browser/printing/print_view_manager_base.h
  chrome/browser/printing/printer_query.cc
  chrome/browser/printing/printer_query.h
  chrome/browser/printing/printing_message_filter.cc
  chrome/browser/printing/printing_message_filter.h
  chrome/common/prerender_messages.h
  chrome/common/print_messages.cc
  chrome/common/print_messages.h
  chrome/renderer/prerender/prerender_helper.cc
  chrome/renderer/prerender/prerender_helper.h
  chrome/renderer/printing/print_web_view_helper.cc
  chrome/renderer/printing/print_web_view_helper_linux.cc
  chrome/renderer/printing/print_web_view_helper_mac.mm
  chrome/renderer/printing/print_web_view_helper_win.cc
  chrome/renderer/printing/print_web_view_helper.h
  chrome/browser/browser_process.cc
  chrome/browser/browser_process.h

The problem areas were:

1. PrintViewManager references PrintPreviewUI and PrintPreviewDialogController.
2. PrintingMessageFilter references ProfileIOData and PrintPreviewUI.
3. Various calls to g_browser_process->GetApplicationLocale() and g_browser_process->print_job_manager().
4. Strings loaded from chrome/app/generated_resources.grd.', '']

['Issue 103751: Fix libgps.so brittleness (remove gpsd support?)', 'Right now, http://codesearch.google.com/#OAMlx_jo-ck/src/content/browser/geolocation/libgps_wrapper_linux.cc&type=cs
attempts to load "libgps.so.19" and if that fails, drops back to "libgps.so"

This is bad, as there's no way to know which version it actually loaded if that succeeds, and future libgps.so.20 appears to have the same set of symbols (so the dlsym will succeed) but uses a different gps_data_t layout, meaning gps usage will be unreliable or even crash.

It's hard to track gps.h versions and harder still to support more than one version of it in a given build, so my inclination is to withdraw gpsd support for desktop linux builds: It was only added as a convenient test platform for the chrome os integration, and it's no longer proving to be convenient, and there is little evidence is used very widely.', '']

['Issue 302732: _blink bots require an issue.', 'There was a recent discussion about transitioning from the _layout bots to the _blink bots and removing the old _layout bots. Because of this discussion I took a look to ensure the new bots provide the same function. However, this does not appear to be the case.

The particular use case in question which does not work on the new bots is applying an arbitrary patch without an associated issue. I often do this to test a set of interrelated Chromium / Blink / Skia changes to ensure that after they all land everything will work out without surprise. For example, a command like

trychange.py --email=example@chromium.org --name=complex_change --file=content/something.cpp --file=third_party/WebKit/Source/core/platform/graphics/skia/something.cpp --file=third_party/skia/src/core/ports/something.cpp --bot=win_layout_rel

works with win_layout_rel (for an example see http://build.chromium.org/p/tryserver.chromium/builders/win_layout_rel/builds/15579 ). However if I change the bot to win_blink_rel this fails with "KeyError: 'issue'" since no issue was specified (for an example see http://build.chromium.org/p/tryserver.chromium/builders/win_blink_rel/builds/8011 ). Not having an issue to update seems like a weak reason to fail.', '']

["Issue 311246: SVG idl's fail to catch erroneous arguments", 'Version: All
OS: All

What steps will reproduce the problem?
      var pathElement = document.createElementNS("http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","path");
      var pathSegment = pathElement.createSVGPathSegCurvetoCubicAbs(0.0633276);

What is the expected output? What do you see instead?

This is not legal, as it is missing 5 more float values. Internally, we have NaN propagating through the code. It should be an error, throw an exception, return a null object and leave the underlying path element unchanged.

This also applies to the canvas path methods, which may or may not currently have the correct behavior (do we even implement them yet?).', '']

['Issue 214442: Move glib IO calls in src/platform repos into libchromeos', 'There's a lot of use of the glib IO channel API in various repos under src/platform:

  (cr) sque@sque ~/trunk/src/platform $ find -name "*.cc" | xargs fgrep -n g_io_add_watch

The repos shown are:
 cros-disks
 shill
 update_engine
 login_manager
 gobi-cromo-plugin
 power_manager
 cashew

I see that shill has some classes to encapsulate GIO already:
http://git.chromium.org/gitweb/?p=chromiumos/platform/shill.git;a=blob;f=glib_io_input_handler.h;h=908ff9c40a63685508f9779948b5b4eea30c3995;hb=HEAD
http://git.chromium.org/gitweb/?p=chromiumos/platform/shill.git;a=blob;f=glib_io_ready_handler.h;h=ffffca121260056e5407f0da4f308e83d6bafeae;hb=HEAD

My proposal:
1. Copy the glib IO code in shill into libchromeos.
2. Modify repos listed above to use the code in glib IO.

This would provide a cleaner way of doing things.

We'd no longer need to create those GIOChannel callbacks.  Instead, we could have a callback like "void CallbackFunc(unsigned char* data, size_t num_bytes)".

We'd no longer have to #include glib.h in header files, which is currently required for the enum GIOCondition.  My understanding is that enums are impossible to forward declare.', '']

['Issue 622130: Quitting Chrome may leave dangerous downloads in a failed state instead of removing them', "Dangerous downloads aren't supposed to survive across session boundaries unless the user accepts them before shutting down Chrome. However, it seems it's possible for dangerous downloads to not be removed and/or the downloads history DB to not be updated to account for the removal.

This results in the dangerous downloads showing up as interrupted during subsequent browser sessions.

Repro:
* start dangerous download
* quit Chrome without accepting said dangerous download.", '']

['Issue 86394: Refactor WebGL canvas and Pepper 3D to use RendererGLContext::CreateParentTexture', 'The task is to move most of the code in the GPU process that deals with textures shared between a "child" and "parent" context into the renderer process. This will make WebGL and Pepper 3D work the same way as accelerated 2D canvas and allow us to remove some redundant code.

It is also a step towards supporting surfaces that can not only be shared between two contexts running in the GPU process but between contexts running in different processes in order to move the issue of compositor related GL / D3D calls to the browser process.

It will also help fix bug 80703, where JavaScript trys to use canvas to render to a newly created window. By deferring the creation of the texture that the canvas uses to share its output with the compositor until the window has actually been created.

The major pieces are:

* Have WebGL and Pepper 3D use RendererGLContext::CreateParentTexture and RendererGLContext::DeleteParentTexture to create their "front buffer" texture.

* Defer the creation until the window and associated view command buffer are created. This can be done as a separate task later.

* Get rid of the code in gles2_cmd_decoder.cc that deals with the management of the offscreen target FBO and offscreen saved texture and do the equivalent in the renderer process instead. This code deals with creating and destroying these objects, resizing them when the canvas resizes, the multisample resolve, setting appropriate attributes for multisampling, texture format (RGB versus RGBA), depth-stencil, etc. As an initial step, the code in the GPU process could be preserved and then removed when everything is moved over in the renderer process.

* We should also be able to eliminate a redundant blit when "swapping" a non-multisampled canvas by doing double buffering and tracking the current "back buffer" and "front buffer" textures in the renderer process itself.

* Make SwapBuffers an error on an offscreen context.

* Remove the notion of a parent / child relationship between contexts. This will mean renaming CreateParentTexture to something like CreateSharedTexture and making the context to share the texture with an additional argument. The contexts need not remember what their parent context is.', '']

['Issue 647852: Mus+Ash: Preserve SurfaceDrawQuads in CompositorFrames', "Each Mus window should:

1. Submit a CompositorFrame.
2. Refer to its children in its CompositorFrame via SurfaceDrawQuads. Each child should have a corresponding SurfaceLayer in the parent's compositor.
3. When surface IDs change in a child, that should propagate to the parent which should update its SurfaceLayer.

I'm glossing over SurfaceSequence stuff because we will change that soon with Jellyfish upstreaming.

According to danakj@, that will give us back some of the occlusion culling optimizations in cc. We still don't get back partial occlusion (if one window [one surface] partially occludes another). We can start thinking about that post-Jellyfish upstreaming.", '']

['Issue 247192: gtests should output the same JSON format as run-webkit-tests', "Right now, gtests output a much more complicated JSON format than run-webkit-tests. We should change gtests to output that same format. The flakiness dashboard server is the only consumer of the gtest JSON output, so there's no reason to keep the current format.

This would simplify the flakiness dashboard server and also have the advantage of making it super-easy to make garden-o-matic work for gtests as well.

I don't think this is terribly high priority, but I figured I should file the bug so that the TODO list related to the flakiness dashboard isn't just in my head.", '']

['Issue 82230: gyp is too damn slow', 'What steps will reproduce the problem?
1. gclient runhooks

What is the expected output? What do you see instead?

Shouldn't drive me insane. Instead, it does.

I played with cProfile and RunSnakeRun. Running gyp_chromium takes 22.9s on my system. Of this, 9.28 seconds are spent in select.select, which is called by subprocess.communicate, which in practice is called mostly for grit_info.py in --inputs and --outputs mode to get the input and output files for grit files (so that gyp can write these dependencies into the project files it generates).

grit_info always does a full parse of a .grd file. This does involved clique computations which aren't needed in --input and --output mode. Adding a nodename-based blacklist to grit's sax parser callback and blacklisting the "messages" element saves most of this unneeded work and reduces gyp_chromium time by 2s. The patch is pretty simple and also pretty safe (I think).

grit can inline images, scripts, and css into html files. In --include mode, some of this is necessary to compute all the included files (an included css file could e.g. include an image), but some of the inlining can be saved (e.g. images will never include other files, so they don't need to be inlined in --include mode).  This reduces gyp_chromium time by 0.5s. The patch is not all that pretty.

Now all the grit_info calls take ~0.13s, but cProfile thinks it's way less than that, which hints at the time going into process creation and inter-process communication. I have a patch that lets gyp check if it's about to run grit_info through subprocess and if so does "import grit_info; grit_info.CallFunction()" in python instead of going through the subprocess dance. This patch is a bit ugly (it makes gyp's grit dependency much more obvious), but it also reduces gyp_chromium time by 5.6 seconds (i.e. a bit over 25%).

(I added
    if __name__ == '__main__':
      cProfile.run('main()', 'profile')
do the bottom of build/gyp_chromium and then just ran "runsnake profile")', '']

['Issue 128553: touch event radiusY is bogus on link', "If we're going to be exposing radius to web sites, we should expect some to start to depend on it.  We should make sure we're either doing it right, or just not expose it for now.

In particular, on link radiusY is always '2'.  The spec says it should be 1 if unknown: https://dvcs.w3.org/hg/webevents/raw-file/tip/touchevents.html#widl-Touch-radiusY.  It seems even more reasonable to me to just always use the same value as radiusX (just not some bogus value like 2).

Also it looks like these are supposed to be CSS pixel values - are we correctly dividing by the device scale factor?

The scale also seems too low - should we scale it up a bit in the driver to be a better approximation of how many pixels are covered by the touch?  A rough approximation is fine I think.  Playing with http://www.corp.google.com/~rbyers/tests/paint.html I'd say it's too small by at least a factor of 2.", '']

['Issue 33622: webgl: shadertoy can crash my display driver', 'http://www.iquilezles.org/apps/shadertoy/

Select either:
- 3D / Mandelbulb
- 3D / Leizex

On my Z600 on vista64, the display driver crashes (fortunately, the OS seems 
to handle it).', '']

['Issue 487272: Expose WebScreenInfo to OOPI', "OOPI are associated with a RWHVChildFrame which doesn't know anything about the native platform. That means that some information like the WebScreenInfo are not properly propagated to the iframe.\n\nA simple way to check that is to try to read window.screen from an iframe. It will return a default screen (width=0, height=0). It should return the same screen as the parent frame.", '']

['Issue 57890: Clean up ownership of MenuItemView/MenuController', "Currently it's possible for MenuItemView to be deleted while the menu is showing. This makes it painful for callers to deal with. MenuItemView needs to be reworked such that MenuController is the only place handling deletion.", '']

['Issue 686974: Mac mini jobs expiring', "Jobs on the mac mini builder are expiring. https://luci-milo.appspot.com/buildbot/chromium.perf/Mac%20Mini%208GB%2010.12%20Perf/

This appears to be because the total amount of time required to run the test suites is longer than 6 hours. 

I'm investigating why tests are taking longer than they should be.", '']

['Issue 47064: Black/flickering favicon shown for partially loaded pages with cairo 1.9', "Chrome Version (from the about:version page): 6.0.444.0 (Developer Build 50329) Debian
Is this the most recent version: Pretty much.
OS + version: Debian unstable
CPU architecture (32-bit / 64-bit): amd64
Window manager: Metacity

What steps will reproduce the problem?
1. Goto a site, any site with a favicon
2. Wait for page to load

What is the expected result?

Either the final or no favicon shown for a site until it's loaded.

What happens instead?

Black flickering square shown until page finishes loading, then the right favicon is shown.", '']

['Issue 328738: Pressing on the default Chrome icon keeps creating more windows when another profile is opened.', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/31.0.1650.63 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. Add more profile/s
2. Delete the default profile
3. Launch chrome a few times from the default icon

What is the expected behavior?
Each launch should minimize/restore the chrome window

What went wrong?
Each launch opens a new window

Did this work before? No 

Chrome version: 31.0.1650.63  Channel: stable
OS Version: 6.1 (Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2)
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 11.9 r900', '']

['Issue 393913: DevTools: Option to log all uncaught promise rejections', "People are starting to use promises in anger & I'm hearing lots of debugging complaints.

As a quick solution, can we have an option to log rejections to the console if a promise is end-of-chain? I hacked something together here http://jsbin.com/xozev/3/edit?js,console, but it doesn't hit all the cases (would need to make a proper subclass to do so).

I understand that catches can be attached to a promise asynchronously, which is why this should be an option and not default.", '']

['Issue 219105: Split ltp out from Autotest for easier code inspection/suite creation', "To enhance kernel testing we need to make greater use of ltp's available tests and features (memory stress).  Currently ltp resides under Autotest as a downloaded binary.  It is difficult to skim code and see what is available as well to debug issues when they arise.  \n\nBreaking ltp out into it's own repo will make a simpler path for building ltp and for adding/debugging kernel tests (as Autotest wrappers) and suites (in Autotest).", '']

['Issue 576754: PointerEventFactory refactoring into PointerEventManager', 'Change PointerEventFactory class into PointerEventManager and move over more code from EventHandler class to it to get it ready for capturing APIs.', '']

['Issue 583376: Pointerover/enter should be sent before pointerdown and pointerout/leave after pointerup on touch screens', 'In one of the W3C pointerevent tests:
pointerevent_pointerenter_nohover-manual

it expects to get a pointerenter before the pointerdown as the pointer needs to enter the div to then fire pointerdown but it is not the case in Chrome.', '']
['Issue 334184: Eliminate Profile dependency from MutablePO2TS', 'This means injecting the TokenWebData and URLRequestContextGetter that the MutablePO2TS should use.', '']

['Issue 331092: Disable ScaleGestureDetector\'s "QuickScale" double-tap drag zoom', 'ContentViewGestureHandler currently implements double-tap drag zoom.  However, Android has implemented this feature with the latest version of the platform ScaleGestureDetector (API 19).  We should remove the custom code from ContentViewGestureHandler, and modify it and ZoomManager accordingly to use the detection code in ScaleGestureDetector.', '']

['Issue 601086: Add MediaError field with informative text for PIPELINE_ERROR and MEDIA_ERROR_LOG_ENTRY errors', 'As of https://codereview.chromium.org/1858073002/, some of these errors can be exposed to devtools console (and later, perhaps, as a message attribute on MediaError to web-apps).\n\nThis bug tracks improving the quality of information reported by replacing numeric error codes with informative text.', '']

['Issue 55441: Fix TabWindowController knowing about browser-specific SplitViews', "A CL was recently landed that introduced knowledge of devtools into TabWindowController, which I really don't like.\n\nRohit suggested this was easy to fix by making the split views owned by their controllers and inserted into the FastResizeView at runtime rather than in the nib.", '']

['Issue 155296: per-data-type throttling can cause scheduler to "forget" a nudge', 'If type X is throttled and we receive a nudge for that type, we'll save a nudge for later.  If a nudge for type Y is scheduled, it will be coalesced with the pending nudge for X.  

That job will run, and when we calculate the items to commit in GetCommitIds, we'll filter out type X, and the job will complete successfully (though it only acted on type Y). The nudge that we "saved for later" in the first sentence of this bug is now gone.

Note though, 1) we don't issue canary jobs for PDT types and 2) PDT doesn't use scheduler-level WaitIntervals, so there's no timer that would fire to check if there's a pending job.  So the actual impact of this bug is limited in that whenever a nudge occurs post-throttle expiration, that nudge will act on all types.  We'll lose notification hints. (Although in practice that shouldn't be a big deal, given that throttle_time is likely to be >> replication delay. It could be an issue if we ever stuff more data in the hints).

What to do

We should probably start by making the scheduler more aware of PDT, what types are throttled, and when they expire. rlarocque has many thoughts on this.

We could enforce that sessions with throttled types shouldn't allow themselves to be coalesced with sessions that aren't for the same type -- if a nudge is scheduled for a throttled type, it could just live in isolation on the message loop until its throttle expires and we wouldn't necessarily even need to keep any references to it.  That wouldn't be ideal for the SESSIONS data type, since we'd likely want to coalesce nudges if that type was throttled.  

Alternatively, we could make SyncSessionJob::Finish actually expose / return what did and did not happen to the scheduler, so it could make some smart decisions based on that and PDT state.', '']

['Issue 583082: merge MediaCodec driver loops', 'This is a tracking issue.

AndroidAudioDecoder and AndroidVideoDecodeAccelerator share significant logic to drive MediaCodec.  These should be merged into one object (MediaCodecLoop, perhaps).  The timer, buffer management, etc., can be rolled into MediaCodecLoop.

this will simplify AAD and AVDA, unit testing, and prevent parallel maintenance.', '']

["Issue 703691: powerd shouldn't disable keyboards that also include power buttons", 'For issue 661368, powerd started configuring input devices while in tablet mode.

We have the following udev rules (in 90-powerd-id.rules) to mark devices as internal keyboards:

SUBSYSTEM=="input", ENV{ID_INPUT_KEYBOARD}=="1",    DRIVERS=="atkbd",        ENV{POWERD_ROLE}="internal_keyboard"
SUBSYSTEM=="input", ENV{ID_INPUT_KEYBOARD}=="1",    DRIVERS=="cros-ec-keyb", ENV{POWERD_ROLE}="internal_keyboard"

and the following (in 91-powerd-tags.rules) to make internal keyboards usable (for both input and wakeup) only while in laptop and display-off modes (i.e. not tablet or docked):

ENV{POWERD_ROLE}=="internal_keyboard",    ENV{POWERD_TAGS_USABLE}="usable_when_laptop usable_when_display_off"
ENV{POWERD_ROLE}=="internal_keyboard", KERNEL=="input*", ENV{POWERD_TAGS_WAKEUP}="wakeup wakeup_only_when_usable"

We have some partner bugs (http://b/36403242, http://b/35872420) about power buttons not working while in tablet mode on some devices. It sounds like this may be due to power button events coming in through the keyboard driver (atkbd, I think) and thus being suppressed in some modes. This arrangement seems non-ideal but I suspect there's nothing we can do about it (besides hopefully avoiding it in the future). :-/

We need to make powerd stop inhibiting keyboards that include the power button, I assume. (I think that Chrome will still ignore key events while in tablet mode.) What's the right way of doing this? Should we introduce a new "internal_keyboard_with_power_button" tag that's tagged as being usable in all modes?

Do we also need to enable wakeup for these keyboards while in tablet mode, or will the power button still work for exiting S3 regardless of what powerd does? It would be unfortunate if regular keys woke convertible Chromebooks that are in tablet mode.

I'm not sure that powerd is able to disable wakeup in a mode while still leaving the device usable while awake. Is that something that we need here?', '']

['Issue 164384: App Host can be left dangling after Chrome uninstall', "Repro steps:

1    Install Chrome at system-level.
2    Install a platform app.
3    Opt-out of the Launcher.
4    Uninstall Chrome.

Expected: Chrome is gone, Google Update is gone (unless it was present prior to step 1).

Actual: User-level Google/Chrome directory is present and contains app_host.exe. Google Update is installed at user-level, with active Client keys for the App Host.

If Chrome is at user-level we handle this by removing the App Host when Chrome is uninstalled. But for system-level Chrome uninstallations we don't have that option.

Possible Remedies:

1. Don't use the App Host without the Launcher. Pros: easy. Cons: desktop shortcuts to platform apps will break if Chrome moves from user- to system-level.
2. Schedule a task at log-in to run setup.exe to detect and remove a dangling App Host. Pros: Relatively easy. Cons: introduces latency during log-in. Some Chrome-related software sticks around for an arbitrary period after uninstallation.

See bug 164064 for an example of this problem.", '']

['Issue 156925: Windowing API documentation', 'http://developer.chrome.com/apps/app.window.html is pretty sparse. Things that it should mention:

- The "id" property and how that interacts with window bounds restoring
- The "onClosed" event (bug 156674 is about the docs system not being able to handle the event, but we can at least mention it in the hand-written docs)
- What state the window is in in the create callback (bug 148857)
- Accuracy/expected lag of the window property getters
- DOM property getters/setters to avoid, and equivalent AppWindow methods

Some of this could be in http://developer.chrome.com/apps/app_lifecycle.html#create_windows, but I think that's not meant to be comprehensives, so I think it's better to centralize it in the API docs with links to it from the lifecycle article.', '']

['Issue 645630: Define min time for live region changes on the same node', 'Live regions are slow enough it is having a user-perceivable impact.

- Blink fires a live region changed event (render accessibility)
- the event is received in the browser (render frame host)
- the event arrives in a listening extension (automation internal custom bindings)

Scope downward thereafter as needed.', '']

['Issue 294468: Possibly keep credentials from signup forms even when another form scores higher', 'When we see a password form, we score each matching credential from the same origin and only show those credentials with the highest score. We currently have an exception for imported Firefox logins and generated passwords, but really all signup forms should be exempted as well. My undestanding is that this check is trying to segregate two different login forms on the same origin (say normal login + admin login).\n\nOne way to broaden this exception might be to add metadata to PasswordForm saying if the Autofill servers responded with ACCOUNT_CREATION_FORM for the password field. If so, then we skip scoring in the future.', '']

['Issue 440754: DevTools: Show service Worker script HTTP request in main devtools window', 'Chrome Version       : 40.0.2214.28
OS Version: Linux 3.16.0-24-generic Ubuntu 14.10 x86_64

It's not really easy to explain so bear with me.

In http://www.w3.org/TR/service-workers/#soft-update-algorithm it says the UA can try to update the Service Worker script "as often as it likes". Jake Archibald says in it's articles that Chrome does it on each navigation change.

When I was trying out SW, I used a simple local static HTTP server that was unfortunately configured with some cache. It prevented me from installing a new version of the SW. I think a lot of people will encounter the same problem.

I wanted to verify what were the cache headers served for the SW script to fix the problem but it was not that simple.

Here's what I found out :

There are two conditions to see the HTTP request for the SW script in devtools/network panel :
* no SW is RUNNING
* you have enabled "Opens the DevTools window for ServiceWorker on start for debugging" in chrome://serviceworker-internals/. 

In a first-ever visit case, you visit the page the SW start for installation, the devtools opens in a popup and pause. At that time you can the see request for the SW that is installing.

Following this example if you navigate (or reload the page) you won't see the HTTP request that Chrome does to check update on the script. Server logs, Wireshark (and Jake) proves Chrome does.

If you modify the SW script, you'll wan't to stop the running SW to be able to see it in network panel. But since there's an update, there's devtools popups. One for the currently installed SW and one for the new version. The HTTP request for the new SW script can be seen but in the devtools popup of the previous version.

What I proposed :

I really think devtools should log all HTTP requests for SW. It was already a problem with AppCache. It will also be more transparent for new comers what happens behind the scenes.

The question is where to log these requests ? For that matter, I'm a bit puzzled...

Random ideas : a new tab for service workers in network panel to see if it's an already installed/running one or a new.

What do you think?', '']

["Issue 443725: Label elements aren't focusable from keyboard tabbing", "UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_10_1) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/39.0.2171.52 Safari/537.36

['Issue 446108: URL input type with leading and trailing whitespace is not stripped', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:34.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/34.0

Example URL:
http://jsfiddle.net/05psx0tv/

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. Load the http://jsfiddle.net/05psx0tv/
2. Test should pass.
3. 

What is the expected behavior?
According to spec https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/forms.html#url-state-%28type=url%29 
Sanitization algorithm should strip leading and trailing whitespace from the value. So in example length of the value should have been 4, but Chrome outputs 6.
FireFox works as expected and strips the leading and trailing whitespaces.

What went wrong?
We are not applying sanitization algorithm for URL Input type,
So it is not stripping whitespace.

Does it occur on multiple sites: N/A

Is it a problem with a plugin? No 

Did this work before? N/A 

Does this work in other browsers? Yes 

Chrome version: 40.0.2214.45 (Official Build) beta-m  Channel: beta
OS Version: 6.1 (Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2)
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 16.0 r0

If someone confirms this is a bug, then I would like to work on this.', '']

['Issue 468447: Change default printer logic in Chrome Print Preview', "Forking work for this partial fix from issue 232038:

We should update default printer logic in Chrome to the following:
1) If there is a last-used printer Print Preview should default to it, else:
2) If there is a system default printer, Print Preview should default to it, else:
3) Chrome should select the first real printer it finds (not PDF, not FedEx, not virtual printers)

There's nuance here, especially around #2 and differentiating real vs. virtual printers on OS' (such as Windows XPS printer, or CutePDF, etc.)

Aleks has offered to pick this up in addition to his current efforts, should be ready in May.", '']

['Issue 471738: add policy to disable dinosaur game on the network error screen on desktop/mobile platforms', "http://crbug.com/462221 tracked a FR to block the dinosaur game on enrolled ChromeOS devices, but we have no policy-based way to block the game on other platforms (they can disable it via a cmd-line flag, but that's it).

We need to figure out how/if we want to address this - I can think of a few options:

0) Do nothing - let people figure out how to pass in a cmd-line flag on desktop platforms, and do nothing on mobile.
1) Add a platform/GPO policy to disable this - this doesn't cover mobile.
2) Do #1, plus add a cloud policy + MDM support to disable this (we probably should've done this to begin with, but this requires server-side involvement).
3) Do #1, and just automatically disable for anyone who is getting cloud policy (requires some work, because currently the implementation is per-chrome-instance, not per-profile). This doesn't help MDM-managed Chrome, however.

Assigning to Cyrus to triage/determine priority and the solution.", '']

['Issue 490787: [Media Router] Handle connection / event page failures to component extension', "This is a bug to track adding logic to handle various failure cases in Media Router's connection to the provider manager component extension:

- OnConnectionError() - if it happens between Bind() and ProvideMediaRouter(), then we should probably flush pending requests.
- Waking the component extension failed - should probably do the same.

In addition, it would be good to introduce a timeout for mojo connection, e.g., if it takes too long for mojo connection to happen after extension wakes up, we should also have failure handling for that.", '']

['Issue 490809: Add a "Print friendly" option to the print preview dialog', 'Web printing is generally very poor experience because most webpages print with navigation, ads, share button and other elements not relevant for print.

DOM Distiller is currently being implemented for delivering better reading experience for Chromium users by removing ads, navigation, etc.

We would like to improve web printing experience by extending DOM Distiller’s functionality for Web Prints. The intent is to add a new checkbox in the Print Dialog to generate a new print PDF using Dom-Distiller.

When the "Print friendly" option is activated, the DOM Distiller will process the page in a hidden WebContents. The processed version of the page will be shown and printed in place of the original.', '']
