Labeling as M46 for now, even if it's a bit ambitious.", '']

['Issue 504513: Security panel: Update language for Overview bullets', 'Strawman examples from [1]:

The site's certificate chain contains an expired certificate (NET::ERR_CERT_DATE_INVALID).
The site's certificate chain contains a certificate that is not considered valid yet (NET::ERR_CERT_DATE_INVALID).
The site's certificate chain contains a certificate that is not signed by a trusted certificate authority (NET::ERR_CERT_AUTHORITY_INVALID).
This site is using a certificate that is not valid for its hostname (NET::ERR_CERT_COMMON_NAME_INVALID).
The site's certificate chain contains an invalid certificate (NET::ERR_CERT_INVALID).
The site's certificate chain contains a certificate that is valid for more than 39 months (NET::ERR_CERT_VALIDITY_TOO_LONG).
The site's certificate chain contains a certificate that was revoked by its issuer (NET::ERR_CERT_REVOKED).

We should work with ainslie@ on these.
Some of these should probably be more actionable, e.g. "This site is using a certificate that is not valid for its hostname (NET::ERR_CERT_COMMON_NAME_INVALID). The website's hostname should be listed in as a Subject Alternative Name (SAN) in the certificate."

[1] https://docs.google.com/document/d/10chp6Tvzl_50gPoIbyc55G76M0I5ecI6Z23r7XKVFg4/edit#heading=h.z3gr2ceauv3u', '']

['Issue 504522: DevTools: [security] Prompt the user to reload', "Issue 502118 (☂ Surface connection information in the DevTools security panel) is about showing the user connection info for resources on the page, but the Security panel won't have access to these events until we open it*.

We need to decide what to show in the main view/sidebar when DevTools opens.


*The Security panel is lazily initialized right now, and the Security domain won't listen for events until that happens. We considered disabling the domain while the panel showing (crrev.com/1196473004), but didn't go ahead. In the future, we may want the Security panel to be initialized when DevTools starts, but that", '']

['Issue 507796: Isolate and swarm telemetry tests (telemetry_unittests, telemetry_perf_unittests, etc.)', 'The unittests from content/test/gpu are now being run on the CQ as of Issue 495868 in the telemetry_gpu_unittests step. Currently, they're being run serially, and it would be ideal to be able to isolate and swarm them, along with the preexisting telemetry_unittests and telemetry_perf_unittests steps.

To do so, based on advice from iannucci@, it seems possible to include a wrapper script in the isolate which obeys the basic contract of ScriptTest (from chromium_tests/steps.py in the tools/build workspace) -- basically, that it is obeys a command line argument --output [filename] or similar, to which simplified JSON output is written.

generate_script could then be modified to look for a new key for each script test in e.g. src/testing/buildbot/chromium.win.json, perhaps:
   "use_isolate": true

The generated test would then look a lot like GTestTest, invoking the target isolate via runtest.py, rather than having the script in the Chromium workspace look for runtest.py. This would also avoid the need to migrate recipes into the Chromium repository simply to isolate and swarm these Telemetry tests.

As a note I intend to work on this, but only after Issue 495870 is fixed. Happy to help if someone else wants to take it in the meantime.', '']

['Issue 518920: VP9 encoder constantly generates new frames when nothing is changing on the screen.', 'Repro steps:

  - Connect to a host.
  - Observe frame-rate close to 30fps even when nothing is changing on the screen.

This appears to be caused cyclic refresh. VP9 keeps returning non-empty active map (same for every frame) and as result the host keeps sending frames to the client.', '']

['Issue 520101: WebRTC should not collect local address unless mic/camera permission is granted.', 'In light of some abuse case where website uses webrtc to fingerprint machines by collecting its local addresses, WebRTC should only expose default route (i.e. multiple_routes disabled) unless mic/camera permission granted for this session or from cached results (i.e. granted for https site).', '']

['Issue 520425: Add UMA stats for repeated audio patterns.', 'Recently, repeated audio has been frequently reported. It is not clear which part of Chromium causes it, or probably the OS.\n\nTo help understand the problem, we can add UMA stats for repeated audio patterns. It will have to sit as early as possible in the audio capturing chain to access the raw data for the ease of detection, but late enough to be able to capture all repetitions of interest.', '']

['Issue 524569: Datalist closes immediately when text input is focused and has a selection', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/43.0.2357.125 Safari/537.36

['Issue 526912: Javascript animated rotation on composited layer ignores image-rendering: pixelated', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_9_5) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/45.0.2454.78 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:

top-most image is without will-change set, image-rendering set to "pixelated", with animated transforms.

bottom-left image is with will-change set to "transform", image-rendering set to "pixelated", and animated transforms. Note the blur.

bottom-left image is with will-change set to "transform", image-rendering set to "pixelated', and NO animated transforms. Note the crisp edges.

What is the expected behavior?
will-change should not affect whether or not the image-rendering filter is applied when scaling images.

What went wrong?
This only seems to happen under the following conditions:

- will-change set to "transform"
- image-rendering set to "pixelated"

['Issue 528089: Peer Connections: renegotiation fails when opposite direction to original offer/answer', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.10; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0

Example URL:
https://output.jsbin.com/xiqogi

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. Go to https://output.jsbin.com/xiqogi
2. Allow access to your camera.
2. Click pub->sub. A second video appears.
3. Click sub->pub.

What is the expected behavior?
The second video does not freeze, and the third video does not appear.

(The third video appears because the peerconnection with the getUserMedia stream attached triggers its onstreamadded callback.)

What went wrong?
The second video freezes and a third (only black) video appears.

Did this work before? N/A 

Is it a problem with Flash or HTML5? HTML5

Does this work in other browsers? Yes 

Chrome version: 47.0.2500.0  Channel: canary
OS Version: OS X 10.10
Flash Version: 

The generated SDP is wrong - in the pub->sub case pub is a=sendrecv and sub is a=recvonly. In the sub->pub case sub is a=sendonly and pub is a=recvonly.

After clicking sub->pub, if you click pub->sub again the third video disappears (onstreamremoved is called) and the second video resumes.', '']

['Issue 528678: An output stream to allow streaming file download from webpage to file system.', 'Feature request:\n\nAn output stream which blobs can be appended to. This would allow streaming download of files generated in the browser, without being limited by having the file fit into ram. The output stream could be passed to window.URL.createObjectURL or similar. However, the download would block for data until the stream is closed.', '']

['Issue 528943: SVG images containing filters do not print', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:40.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/40.0 Example URL: Steps to reproduce the problem: 1. I created an SVG image using filters (with the 'Drop shadow...' function of Inkscape) 2. I created an HTML page embedding that image with a tag 3. I printed (or "print previewed") that page (see for example [http://champin.net/2015/ff-svg-filter-dpi/]) What is the expected behavior? The whole SVG image should be printed with an appropriate resolution. What went wrong? The part of the SVG image which is submitted to the filter is badly rasterized. Note that the rest of the SVG image is printed correctly. I understand that filters impose a rasterization, but the default resolution (DPI) of that rasterization when printing is clearly too small, and I didn't find any way to change it (neither in the print dialog nor in the settings). Does it occur on multiple sites: N/A Is it a problem with a plugin? No Did this work before? N/A Does this work in other browsers? No Firefox 40 Chrome version: 44.0.2403.89 Channel: n/a OS Version: Flash Version:', '']

["Issue 529295: touch-action zoom state shouldn't reset at scrollers", 'Test page: http://jsbin.com/tipure/

On Edge / IE: double-tapping on the scroller does not zoom, and taps are registered immediately.
In Chrome, double-tapping the scroller does zoom.

This means the simple guidance "use 'touch-action: manipulation' to disable the click delay" isn't actually sufficient.

I believe blink matches the spec, but we should change the spec and blink to match the Edge behavior (will start a thread on public-pointer-events).

In particular, we probably want to keep walking up the tree beyond scrollers to consider just the zoom-related parts of touch-action.  Let's wait to see what exact wording the PEWG agrees on for the spec though.', '']

['Issue 530342: Render Unicode control characters', 'A few months ago, the CSSWG realized that all the browsers were
violating Unicode, by not rendering non-WS control characters
<https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-style/2014Mar/0475.html>.

It was decided that it made sense to match Unicode (and, likely, other
software) and display them instead. As such the spec has been updated to address this:

   # Control characters (Unicode category Cc) other than tab (U+0009),
   # line feed (U+000A), and carriage return (U+000D) must be rendered
   # as a visible glyph and otherwise treated as any other character
   # of the Other Symbols (So) general category and Common script.
   # The UA may use a glyph provided by a font specifically for the
   # control character, substitute the glyphs provided for the
   # corresponding symbol in the Control Pictures block, generate a
   # visual representation of its codepoint value, or use some other
   # method to provide an appropriate visible glyph. As required by
   # [UNICODE], unsupported Default_ignorable characters must be
   # ignored for rendering.

<https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-style/2014Oct/0391.html>

In order to minimize the impact of the change for web developers the major browser vendors have all agreed to flip the switch around the same time frame. We're targeting Chrome 47 which fits the agreed "around November" timeline.', '']
['Issue 530723: tab and desktop capture tracks should fire onended event', 'desktop captured stream fires it. but not for tab capturing', '']

['Issue 531990: Launch Shadow DOM v1', 'Change description:
Launch Shadow DOM v1

Changes to API surface:
- Element.attachShadow
- New HTML Element: HTMLSlotElement
- NonDocumentTypeChildNode.assignedSlot
- Event.deepPath

Links:
Public standards discussion: https://github.com/w3c/webcomponents/labels/v1
The spec: http://w3c.github.io/webcomponents/spec/shadow/

Support in other browsers:
Internet Explorer: Not yet
Firefox: Not yet
Safari: Not yet', '']

['Issue 532694: Auto-close MR dialog after user starts casting', "Because we can't support blur-to-close at the moment (see b/24131954), one mitigation would be to automatically close the MR UI after the user selects a device and successfully starts a cast session.  \n\nSuggest we auto-close 3 seconds after we first show the details view upon successfully initiating a cast session, unless the user interacts with some other element in the dialog first.", '']

['Issue 534306: sink ID for media elements is forgotten when src changes.', 'When a new stream is created for a media element, the default device is always used. If setSinkID was used to change the sink ID, this new sink ID is not taken into account in the creation of the new stream associated with the element.', '']

['Issue 534788: Implement "Secure Contexts"', "Changes to API surface:
We're basically spec compliant at this point; we just need some slight modifications to Shared Workers, and to expose the `isSecureContext` boolean.

Links:
Public standards discussion: https://w3c.github.io/webappsec/specs/powerfulfeatures/

Support in other browsers:
Internet Explorer: Nada.
Firefox: Public support.
Safari: Zip.", '']

['Issue 537293: Unprefixed font-feature-settings', 'Change description:
Ship the unprefixed flavor of font-feature-settings and progressively deprecate the -webkit flavor that we currently ship.

Changes to API surface:
CSS font-feature-settings

Links:
https://drafts.csswg.org/css-fonts/#font-feature-settings-prop

Support in other browsers:
Internet Explorer: yes, unprefixed
Firefox: yes, unprefixed and -moz
Safari: no
Opera: yes, -webkit

We should also add:
 1. a RAPPOR metric to better understand what is driving the usage of the prefixed version.
 2. a usage count for the unprefixed version.', '']

['Issue 538600: Change Event.timeStamp to HighResTimeStamp relative to navigationStart', 'Change description:
Change Event.timeStamp to be a high resolution monotonic time Change Event.timeStamp to be a high resolution monotonic time (i.e., DOMHighResTimeStamp) instead of an epoch time. For input events, Event.timeStamp represents the underlying OS timestamp instead of the DOM event creation time.

Changes to API surface:
partial interface Event {
  readonly attribute DOMHighResTimeStamp timeStamp;
}


Links: https://github.com/whatwg/dom/issues/23
Public standards discussion: https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-whatwg-archive/2014May/0055.html


Support in other browsers:
Internet Explorer: No public signal
Firefox: In Development (https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1026804)
Safari:No public signal', '']

['Issue 541190: Permission Bubble shows out of the page it emitted', 'Chrome Version : 47.0.2525.0 I've created a simple web page on a local https server (https://localhost:4443/p.html) HTTPS is required due to security limitations to the geolocation and media APIs. Microphone should exist on the client computer.





LEAVE Now, I open the page, https://localhost:4443/p.html, and 1. Click GEO - a bubble appears, localhost requests the permission to the geolocation 2. Do not touch the bubble! Click MIC 5 times - nothing happens, the bubble persists 3. Do not touch the bubble! Click LEAVE - SUDDENLY, the first bubble cancels and hides, and the next bubble appears, requesting the permission to the microphone. 4. Navigate back and forward 5 times - The requests will show all 5 times, cancelling on each navigation. Reload the page. 5. Click M+G or G+M - a composite bubble with two permission requests (geo and mic) appears 6. Click LEAVE or navigate forward/back. - the bubble cancels and hides. Reload the page. 7. Click M+M+G - a composite bubble with two requests appears. 8. Click LEAVE or navigate. - the bubble cancels, and SUDDENLY, the pending bubble with request to mic appears! Reload the page. 9. Click MIC - a bubble with request to mic appears. 10. Click GEO - nothing happens, yet. 11. Click LEAVE or navigate - the request to mic cancels and hides, and there is no request to geo. Reload the page. 12. Click G+G+M - a bubble with two requests appears. 13. Click LEAVE or navigate - the bubble cancels and hides. Only 5,6 and 12,13 are good. And 9,10,11 look not so bad. Others are UGLY. Expected behavior: 1) when the page requires one more permission (click GEO then click MIC, for instance), the bubble should (would) expand 2) series of requests to same permission (click MIC many times) should join to single request - at least, until the user closes the bubble 3) no request should appear beyond the navigation. The difference between geolocation and microphone is caused with different controllers of permission bubble requests of media and all other kinds. (As far as I has understood your source code). (Did not test your newest master - just tag 47.0.2525.0 and your windows build). WBR, Nickolay Merkin', '']

['Issue 546686: WebGL reports context lost on shader compilation', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/46.0.2490.71 Safari/537.36

2. 
3. 

What is the expected behavior?
The web site should use WebGL run animations 
while scrolling and show a green 3D logo.

What went wrong?
Developer Tools report a CONTEXT_LOST_WEBGL
chrome://gpu reports GpuProcessHostUIShim: You killed the GPU process! Why?

Debugging with developer tools reveals that this
happens on 
   g.getShaderParameter(vs, g.COMPILE_STATUS)
which is called after 
   g.compileShader (vs);

OS Version: 6.3
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 19.0 r0

- the URL parameter ?dbg=t includes non-minimized versions of the libraries, the error occurs with and without this parameter', '']

No vertical scroll bar.

Some variation of this keeps happening!

Somebody finally fixes it, then a new version comes out
and I'm assuming that some developer changed some code, again,
that causes it to fail.

Usually the problem is that there is a scroll bar there, but
you can't scroll with it.  Now the problem is that it's totally gone.

You need to add some notes or something in the code
so developers don't keep breaking it.

Or break the critical part of the code out and
put it somewhere where other developers don't keep
messing it up.

Thanks


Please provide any additional information below. Attach a screenshot if
possible.', '']

['Issue 556261: Supervised users feature issue', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/46.0.2490.86 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. Create a supervised user.
2. Set up all restrictions "prevent supervised user from creating new accounts" . 
3. Then click on the Profile switcher (upper right corner) and select "Exit and Childlock".
4. The supervised user can simply click on the Profile switcher and remove the supervisor user.
5. A new user shows up and the supervised user can use it to access web without restrictions.

What is the expected behavior?
The supervised user mustn't be able to remove the supervisor user. The supervised user mustn't be able to switch users without the supervisor password or permission.

What went wrong?
The supervised user can remove the supervisor user and access web without any restrictions. I reported that in the Google Chrome Help Forum and an expert told me to report that here.

Did this work before? N/A 

Chrome version: 46.0.2490.86  Channel: stable
OS Version: 6.1 (Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2)
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 19.0 r0

The supervised user mustn't be able to remove users or switch users without the permission of the supervisor.', '']

KERNEL_MODE_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED_M (1000008e)
This is a very common bugcheck.  Usually the exception address pinpoints
the driver/function that caused the problem.  Always note this address
as well as the link date of the driver/image that contains this address.
Some common problems are exception code 0x80000003.  This means a hard
coded breakpoint or assertion was hit, but this system was booted
/NODEBUG.  This is not supposed to happen as developers should never have
hardcoded breakpoints in retail code, but ...

system is booted /DEBUG.  This will let us see why this breakpoint is

['Issue 5933: test_shell_tests aborts due to double free on linux with hammer SHARED=1', "glibc is picking up a double free when running test_shell_tests on linux
for rev 7526 of trunk. This is only happening when compiled with SHARED=1.

Here's the tail end of the output ...

 7 FAILED TESTS
Leak 1 JS wrappers.
*** glibc detected *** Hammer/test_shell_tests: double free or corruption
(!prev): 0x09129678 ***
======= Backtrace: =========
/lib/libc.so.6[0xc41874]
/lib/libc.so.6(cfree+0x96)[0xc438d6]
Hammer/test_shell_tests(_ZN2v88internal8Malloced6DeleteEPv+0x11)[0x8147b95]
Hammer/test_shell_tests(_ZN2v88internal4ListIiNS0_25FreeStoreAllocationPolicyEED1Ev+0x25)[0x816f44d]
/lib/libc.so.6(__cxa_finalize+0xc1)[0xc01e91]
/home/craig/chromium/src/webkit/Hammer/dbg/lib/libtest_shell.so[0x2966b44]
/home/craig/chromium/src/webkit/Hammer/dbg/lib/libtest_shell.so[0x2b20fc0]
/lib/ld-linux.so.2[0xdb1f7b]
/lib/libc.so.6(exit+0x89)[0xc01b39]
/lib/libc.so.6(__libc_start_main+0xee)[0xbea5de]
Hammer/test_shell_tests(_ZNSsD1Ev+0x65)[0x8104341]
======= Memory map: ========
[snip]

What seems to be happening is that when libtest_shell.so is unloaded
__cxa_finalize and exit both seem to be trying to free some v8 data.

The actual problem appears to be that libtest_shell.so is linked against v8
which is unnecessary. Only test_shell_tests should be linked to v8.

I'm attaching an ugly patch that does this but there is probably a nice way
of doing this and I'm unsure of the implications for other platforms.

Perhaps this can be assigned to evmar or sgk to fix properly please?", '']

["Issue 7508: We don't anti-alias <canvas> drawImage", "It looks like other browsers anti-alias when images are draw into a
<canvas> tag.  This is easy to see when you use a rotation transform, etc.
 It also looks like we aren't scaling the image nearly as well as other
browsers.

http://pigs.sourceforge.jp/blog/200811140144/uupaa-canvas.js/demo/3_3_canvas_drawimage+trans+clip.html

Compare that example to Firefox, and you can see we are much more pixely.", '']

['Issue 11480: Support GTK keyboard themes (emacs keybindings)', "GTK lets the user specify keyboard bindings via their config file.

This should work for the Omnibox, but it won't work for our renderering 
model.  It's probably a lot of work to, but optimistically you could imagine 
hooks to convert a keystroke into an editing command and we could send the 
editing commands over IPC.", '']

['Issue 14477: Main request fails when certificate revocation check gets empty string / times out', 'What steps will reproduce the problem?
1.  Set up a server that will time out all requests.  (wtc, ask me or 
eroman for where we set ours up)
2.  Set your HOSTS file to point the following domains at this "timeout 
server"
0.0.0.0    crl.verisign.com
0.0.0.0    www.verisign.com
0.0.0.0      SVRIntl-crl.verisign.com
0.0.0.0      ocsp.verisign.com
0.0.0.0      SVRIntl-aia.verisign.com

(replace the 0.0.0.0 with the IP address of your "timeout server"

3.  Navigate to 
https://quickaccess.verizonwireless.com/quickaccess?
olp=zhqz1rYlzlZ5zaBiLRdfef1LksvmMCp3E2Xbt1pi18o6CkJEBg2262qRY%2B5bBzVm


Expected:
See a "certificate could not be verified" info bar, strike through the 
"https" in the omnibox, and the rest of the page loads normally.

Instead:
Error page, showing a 324 error (empty response) or error 7 (timeout)

I reproduced this on 3.0.189 and 2.0.157.', '']

['Issue 30636: chrome does a search when i want to open a website on a custom TLD', 'Chrome Version       : 4.0.249.30 (Official Build 33928) running under Mac OS X
URLs (if applicable) : http://example.com.pre/, http://example.com.dev-bob.pre/, ...
Other browsers tested:
Add OK or FAIL after other browsers where you have tested this issue:
     Safari 4: OK
  Firefox 3.x: OK
         IE 7: OK
         IE 8: OK

What steps will reproduce the problem?
1. enter a URL which your DNS server knows about, but chrome doesn't recognise without a URL scheme. eg: "example.com.pre"
2. press enter

What is the expected result?

A DNS lookup is performed on "example.pre", and upon successful result the page "http://example.com.pre/"

What happens instead?

A google search for "example.pre" is opened with a drop down box "did you mean http://example.com.pre/?"


Please provide any additional information below. Attach a screenshot if
possible.

At our web development company, we have a development copy of all of our clients websites running in our datacentre which is accessed via ".pre" 
as a suffix, and all of our developers have a personal copy of the website available via ".dev-bob.pre" as a suffix. Our local DNS server as well as our 
VPN setup is configured to direct the fake "pre" TLD to the correct server.

This has worked perfectly for us for years with every web browser, but in Chrome we must explicitly enter "http://" before the domain name, which 
is frustrating since we have literally thousands of domain names, and often need to type them in quickly (such as while on a phone call with the 
client).', '']

["Issue 40646: Can't Keep Hyperlink from Executing (jQuery/Chromium)", 'I have added an onclick handler to every hyperlink in my document. That 
onclick handler is supposed to prevent the default behaviour of following 
the Hyperlink. (The onclick event handler updates the current document via 
jQuery.)

But somehow, Chromium doesn't execute the jQuery function 
event.preventDefault(). It always reloads the whole document although it 
shouldn't.

Here's the jQuery onclick code I'm using (it's quite straightforward, so 
jQuery knowledge is not required):

function clickHandler(event)
 {/// <summary>...</summary>
 /// <param name="event">jQuery event object.</param>

 MyNamespace.updatePageContent(MyNamespace.hrefToValue(this));

 event.preventDefault();
 event.stopPropagation();}



In Internet Explorer, everything is working fine...

Here's the URL to my JavaScript application (I'm currently working on the 
style sheets):

http://www.dashop.de/scripts/blog/jQuery/AjQDoc/AjQDoc.html?bookmark=false


Chrome Version       :
Google Chrome 4.1.249.1045 (Offizieller Build 42898)
WebKit 532.5
V8 1.3.18.22
User Agent Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.1; en-US) 
AppleWebKit/532.5 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/4.1.249.1045 Safari/532.5

3.  Click any Hyperlink in the list on the right

The hyperlink is followed.

['Issue 43293: When you change your system time to another timezone and refresh the current tab the getTimezoneOffset is set back to 0', "Chrome Version       : 5.0.375.29 beta
URLs (if applicable) : http://users.telenet.be/doderke/test.html
OS version               : 10.6.3
Behavior in Safari 3.x/4.x (if applicable): OK
Behavior in Firefox 3.x (if applicable): OK
Behavior in Chrome for Windows: untested

What steps will reproduce the problem?
1. Create a webpage with the following javascript code (also see url) and open your javascript 
console to see the output:
t = new Date();
t.getTimezoneOffset();
2. Change you system time to another timezone
3. Refresh your page and look at the output again

What is the expected result?

That the getTimezoneOffset is not set to 0 but adjusted according to the new system timezone.

What happens instead?

In step 1 my system time zone was set to West Greenland Summer Time (Nuuk - Greenland) 
which return the following results in the javascript console: 

Wed May 05 2010 06:38:42 GMT-0200 (WGST)
-7200

In step 2 i changed my timezone (system datetime) to Central European Summer Time (Brussels - 
Belgium) and refreshed the tab (step 3) and got the following results:

Wed May 05 2010 08:45:00 GMT+0000 (UTC)
0

If then open a new tab and type in the same url i get the expected result which should be:

Wed May 05 2010 10:46:39 GMT+0200 (CEST)
7200

Please provide any additional information below. Attach a screenshot if
possible.

If i open a new tab and fill in the url of the tab that gives the incorrect results it's correct. So it 
seems that a already running tab can't adjust itself to time zone change while other browsers like 
safari and firefox can do perfectly. The issue is of course resolved if i close my browser or open a 
new tab after time zone change but i don't think that most users will know that. Since we use this 
in a web application to determine time zone changes it's kind of important that this works.

Maybe this is related to Issue 16800: Date.getTimezoneOffset always returns 0", '']

['Issue 43322: [MD audit] Problems with video messages and sizes', "I think I see a bunch of nearby problems, so I'll assign this to myself for 
now...

---
4. UpdateVideo Out of Bounds Memory Access

File: chrome/gpu/gpu_video_layer_glx.cc
Function: GpuVideoLayerGLX::OnPaintToVideoLayer()
Problem Type: Illegal Memory Access (Read)
Compromise Type: Sandbox escalation
Severity: Medium
Message: ViewHostMsg_UpdateVideo

A shared memory buffer specified by the user is mapped in to the GPU 
process and then used as a source buffer to read pixel data from. However, 
the size of 
the shared memory buffer is not verified against the size of the video size 
set up previously with the ViewHostMsg_CreateVideo message. Therefore, it 
is 
possible to read out of bounds memory data in to the video window, leading 
to potential information leaks.
---", '']

['Issue 50071: Security meta: investigate cross_fuzz crashes, showModalDialog glitch', "My new fuzzer, cross_fuzz (under construction) is triggering tons of Chrome-specific crashes. Most of them seem to be NULL pointers and int3 that are still also triggered by ref_fuzz (bah), but there are also things like this:

FAULT ->0217b246 8b00             mov     eax,[eax]         ds:0023:12db7ff5=????????

Tracking them down is hard because of the fuzzer can't produce simple repros, and there are too many NULL ptr faults that get in the way and limit coverage.

Uncommenting showModalDialog in the fuzzer also causes it to sometimes spawn windows at negative screen coordinates, which feels very wrong and could be abused by rogue sites. I'm having difficulty tracking this down, though; there's nothing special about the parameters passed to showModalDialog, so it must be caused by an earlier DOM tweak to the parent. If we have anyone familiar with that code, it might be good to ping them.

Stable fuzzer URL:
http://lcamtuf.coredump.cx/cross_fuzz/cross_fuzz_mozilla.html", '']

['Issue 76748: Flash object in cross-domain iframe breaks Flash functionality in parent frame', 'Chrome Version       : 10.0.648.151

A Flash object in a top-level frame can't access ExternalInterface if it's inserted after another Flash object is instantiated in an IFRAME.

There is a strange combination of things going on here. Here is what I've found.

Let's say we have outer.html on domain1.com and inner.html on domain2.com:

outer.html
----------
<html><body>
<iframe src="http://domain2.com/inner.html"></iframe>
<script>
var d = document.createElement("div");
document.body.appendChild(d);
d.innerHTML = '<object type="application/x-shockwave-flash" data="myswf.swf" id="id123" ><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"/></object>';
</script>
</body></html>

inner.html
----------
<html><body>
<object type="application/x-shockwave-flash"></object>
</body></html>

myswf.swf is a SWF that wants to use ExternalInterface. With the code shown, it is able to. Strangely, the Chrome Console shows "Unsafe Javascript attempt to access frame with URL http://domain1.com/outer.html from fame with URL http://domain2.com/inner.html. Domains, protocols and ports must match. True, they don't match, but I would only expect to see that warning if I actually tried to do any inter-frame accessing. This is similar to Issue 31068.

Now let's say I don't want to insert myswf.swf right away -- it gets inserted on the page a bit later. So the script contents in outer.html will be surrounded by "setTimeout(function(){.....}, 1000);"

Now Flash in inner.html is instantiated first. Then, the SWF in outer.html is instantiated. When the outer SWF attempts to access ExternalInterface, a SecurityException is seen in Flash, and Chrome Console shows "Unsafe Javascript attempt to access frame with URL http://domain1.com/outer.html from frame with URL http://domain1.com/outer.html. Domains, protocols and ports must match." This isn't right -- the URLs match exactly!

Strangely, this error seems to be caused by the first one. If I remove Flash from the inner frame, the outer Flash doesn't have a problem. If the inner frame is on the same domain as the outer frame, there is no problem. If I go to the Flash Security Settings panel at http://www.macromedia.com/support/documentation/en/flashplayer/help/settings_manager04.html and change "always ask" to "always allow", then this problem doesn't occur. If I remove the Flash object from the inner frame before inserting the Flash object in the outer frame, the Flash object in the outer frame still gets the error blocking ExternalInterface.

So it seems a Flash object in a cross-domain IFRAME, which should be totally isolated from the host page, breaks the functionality of Flash's ExternalInterface on the host page!
But only if the inner frame's Flash is inserted first. And only if the frames are cross-domain. And only if Flash's security setting is "always ask".', '']

['Issue 76865: Chrome can only do putImageData at 10 fps for a small canvas that is scaled up.', 'Chrome Version       : 11.0.696.14 (Official Build 78500) dev
URLs (if applicable) : http://www.grantgalitz.org/gbc_demo/
Other browsers tested:
     Safari 5: FAIL
  Firefox 3.x: N/A - JS engine is too slow to tell
  Firefox 4.x: OK
       IE 7/8: N/A - Cannot run canvas
         IE 9: FAIL
   Opera 11.x: FAIL

What steps will reproduce the problem?
1. Go to the webpage
2. Wait for the ROM image's transfer to complete.
3. View the low FPS and non-fullspeed performance experienced.

What is the expected result?
Fullspeed and smooth gfx.

What happens instead?
Jittery low FPS graphics from chrome taking too long to render a putImageData instance.

Please provide any additional information below. Attach a screenshot if
possible.

I do use RequestAnimationFrame (And I fallback to a regular path if needed.) and there is a frameskip algorithm implemented to skip frames when they take too long to render.

Happens for all ROMs, definitely some serious slowness rendering the framebuffer blocking the execution in the emulator.

Your CPU monitor will not say 100% usage, because when the emulator skips frames from the frameskip algorithm being in effect, google chrome actually finishes "on time" (Hence why the slowness is indeed gfx and NOT JS execution speed.).', '']

['Issue 83106: Tab animations are janky on linux', "Copy of my internal buzz:

Tab drawing on Linux braindump: Currently, tab animation in chrome is janky as hell in the GTK port. I spent the last day trying to track this down to...inconclusive results.

The tab insertion animation (the slide in one) usually has no more than three frames. It lasts 100ms and the first frame is usually rendered 60ms in. This is perceptible; we visually aren't as smooth as the Windows or Mac port. It isn't helping that pprof seems worthless in this situation.

The first and immediate suspicious piece of code is the actual tab rendering. It's a bunch of skia code that is creating a new bitmap each time on the client instead of performing the compositing X server side like the rest of our bitmapped interface. But when I time the expose event, each individual tab takes at most 1ms to render.

The second thing I checked was the message loop. I instrumented the insertion animation so that when the animation began, it would add a MessageLoop/MessagePumpForUI observer to check the number of Tasks and GdkEvent*s that fire between starting the animation. This doesn't really look like a flood either. There are usually 5 Tasks and 10 events processed. One of these events is a GDK_EXPOSE event that takes between 70-100ms. And I have no idea what it is! It doesn't look like the tab strip expose event since I've already instrumented that with timing code.", '']

['Issue 104638: CanFindIntranetURL() should look up dotted hosts based only on last component', 'If we have a potential intranet hostname with dots, e.g. "a.b.c" where there is no known eTLD, then CanFindIntranetURL() in the HUP should look up URLs like "*.c" (with any path) rather than using the full hostname.  This way, navigating to "a.b.c" will teach Chrome that future inputs of "d.e.f.c" are also navigational attempts.\n\nI\'d like to get this in with the other heuristic improvements for intranet users I\'m trying to make for M16.', '']

['Issue 107080: Unable to pin two different user profiles shortcut to taskbar', 'Chrome Version       : 17.0.963.2
OS Version: 6.1 (Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2)

Note:This is Windows 7 specific (Though the same problem might (stress on might) occur in docks used in any OS)

What steps will reproduce the problem?
1.Create two (or more) users in chrome browser
2.Open one of them and pin to taskbar
3.Close the current user window and open another window of a different user and pin this one as well 
4.Now if you click on either of the pinned users the other will vanish and only one icon will be left in the taskbar

It would be better if multiple users are allowed to be pinned to the taskbar. That way its possible to open users without having to goto the desktop and double-clicking on the profile shortcut.

An alternative (to having multiple icons pinned) would be to show the different users in the jump list of a single icon (can be shown under "Tasks" where currently only "New Window" and "New Incognito Window" are available)

What steps will reproduce the problem?
1. download source code; code SVN revision r135761
2. cross-compiled the source code for arm; the cross-compiled instructions are recipe 3 from http://code.google.com/p/chromium/wiki/LinuxChromiumArm
3. launch the browser; the browser window did not show up and the segmentation fault observed. 

What is the expected result?
The browser window shows up


What happens instead?
The segmentation fault occurs and the browser cannot be launched. 


The GYP_DINFES are 

  readonly GYP_DEFINES="\
    target_arch=arm \
    armv7=1 \
    sysroot=${SYSROOT} \
    remoting=0 \
    linux_breakpad=0 \
    disable_nacl_untrusted=1 \
    linux_use_tcmalloc=0
  "


Please provide any additional information below. Attach a screenshot if
possible.

=========================================
For the save source code, if we first build a chromiumOS and then build the chrome browser inside chroot environment, the chrome browser can be launched with aura_root window. This time GYP defines are 

 * system_libdir=lib
 * pkg-config=pkg-config-arm-generic
 * use_xi2_mt=2
 * swig_defines=-DOS_CHROMEOS
 * chromeos=1
 * use_ibus=1
 * target_arch=arm
 * armv7=1
 * v8_can_use_unaligned_accesses=true
 * remoting=1
 * remove_webcore_debug_symbols=1
 * order_text_section=/var/cache/distfiles/target/chrome-src/pgo/section-ordering-files/orderfile
 * strip_tests=1
 * use_aura=1
 * linux_use_tcmalloc=0
 * use_cras=1
 * internal_pdf=0
 * release_extra_cflags='-g'
=====================================

We need a chromium browser with use_aura=0 and chromeos=0.  If we cross-compile the code, then the segmentation faults occurs and the browser window does not show up.  

If we set use_aura=0/chromeos=0 insde chrome, build/gyp_chromium fails.  

Any suggestion on how to resolve this issue will be greatly appreciated.', '']

['Issue 142360: Native implement of require() for extensions', "Using <script> tags to load JavaScript in extensions is rather a blunt instrument and doesn't lead naturally to modular software architectures. With the new CSP restrictions, it isn't possible for extensions to load scripts any other way, however, even when the scripts are safe and reside in the extension directory.

It would be very helpful to have a require() function identical to that used by Node.js available to Chrome extensions. It could be used to load scripts from the extension directory as an alternative to the <script> tag. In addition to providing an elegant way to modularize code and handle namespaces, it would make it possible to use the wealth of CommonJS modules written for Node.js and not compatible with normal web environments.

Note that the Mozilla Addon SDK, which is in many ways inspired by the Chrome extension API, supports require() and CommonJS modules natively.

I'm interested in trying to implement this. Before doing so, however, I wanted to check whether (a) this is a non-starter that will never be accepted into Chromium or (b) someone is already working on this.", '']

['Issue 144832: It is time to unlink the "Backspace" -> Browser Back shortcut.', 'Browsers have inherited the "Backspace" shortcut to go back from antiquity, in the days when the web was far more static, before tabs, before webapps, before things like Google Docs and Chrome OS meant that browsers are used to create documents, sometimes documents that take hours to compose. 

Take an informal survey of your friends, and average the number of hours of work that each of them has lost due to hitting the "backspace" button trying to delete a word, but having that action move the browser back a page. This is unacceptable, and an inheritance of an archaic shortcut does not outweigh the damage that it causes. It is time to break backwards compatibility on this shortcut and force people to learn Alt + <- or one of the other back shortcuts, and allow "Backspace" to mean "Backspace" only. 

I am aware that while typing in a field (like this one) the backspace button will delete letters and not move the browser back, but it is all too easy (and too common) for the field to lose focus (for a myriad of reasons: an unintentional palm-touch to a trackpad, a moment of multitasking, focus stealing scripts or popups, an accidental "tab" press or some other shortcut). It's time to stop being bogged down by the past and do what is best for billions. Weigh the costs of the few minutes it takes people to learn a new shortcut against the cost of hours of work being lost over and over and over by the majority of web users.', '']

['Issue 159808: Chrome 25 has a significant drop in performance using WebGL with requestAnimationFrame', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.18 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/25.0.1318.0 Safari/537.18

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. On Chrome 22 Run http://biz.turbulenz.com/samples#sample-modal/samplepage/sample_assets/multiple_animations.canvas.release.html/samplesrc/sample_assets/multiple_animations.js.html and set it to use 400 Character. On my system (Windows 7, ATI Radeon 6800) this runs at 60Hz.

What is the expected behavior?
As good as performance as previous versions of Chrome.

What went wrong?

['Issue 166485: Leak in file_util::CreateDirectory() calling std::vector::push_back', "This leak is showing up on the Linux and ChromeOS valgrind bots:
  http://build.chromium.org/p/chromium.memory.fyi/builders/Chromium%20OS%20%28valgrind%29%285%29/builds/12945
  http://build.chromium.org/p/chromium.memory.fyi/builders/Linux%20Tests%20%28valgrind%29%283%29/builds/19198
  http://build.chromium.org/p/chromium.memory.fyi/builders/Linux%20Tests%20%28valgrind%29%284%29/builds/15561
  http://build.chromium.org/p/chromium.memory.fyi/builders/Linux%20Tests%20%28valgrind%29%285%29/builds/14227

Leak_DefinitelyLost
262 (64 direct, 198 indirect) bytes in 1 blocks are definitely lost in loss record 51,312 of 63,247
  operator new(unsigned long) (m_replacemalloc/vg_replace_malloc.c:1140)
  __gnu_cxx::new_allocator<FilePath>::allocate(unsigned long, void const*) (/usr/include/c++/4.4/ext/new_allocator.h:89)
  std::_Vector_base<FilePath, std::allocator<FilePath> >::_M_allocate(unsigned long) (/usr/include/c++/4.4/bits/stl_vector.h:140)
  std::vector<FilePath, std::allocator<FilePath> >::_M_insert_aux(__gnu_cxx::__normal_iterator<FilePath*, std::vector<FilePath, std::allocator<FilePath> > >, FilePath const&) (/usr/include/c++/4.4/bits/vector.tcc:322)
  std::vector<FilePath, std::allocator<FilePath> >::push_back(FilePath const&) (/usr/include/c++/4.4/bits/stl_vector.h:741)
  file_util::CreateDirectory(FilePath const&) (base/file_util_posix.cc:594)
  dom_storage::DomStorageContext::GetStorageNamespace(long) (webkit/dom_storage/dom_storage_context.cc:69)
  dom_storage::DomStorageContext::DeleteLocalStorage(GURL const&) (webkit/dom_storage/dom_storage_context.cc:130)
Suppression (error hash=#0C073FDF42B3D847#):
  For more info on using suppressions see http://dev.chromium.org/developers/tree-sheriffs/sheriff-details-chromium/memory-sheriff#TOC-Suppressing-memory-reports
{
   <insert_a_suppression_name_here>
   Memcheck:Leak
   fun:_Znw*
   fun:_ZN9__gnu_cxx13new_allocatorI8FilePathE8allocateEmPKv
   fun:_ZNSt12_Vector_baseI8FilePathSaIS0_EE11_M_allocateEm
   fun:_ZNSt6vectorI8FilePathSaIS0_EE13_M_insert_auxEN9__gnu_cxx17__normal_iteratorIPS0_S2_EERKS0_
   fun:_ZNSt6vectorI8FilePathSaIS0_EE9push_backERKS0_
   fun:_ZN9file_util15CreateDirectoryERK8FilePath
   fun:_ZN11dom_storage17DomStorageContext19GetStorageNamespaceEl
   fun:_ZN11dom_storage17DomStorageContext18DeleteLocalStorageERK4GURL
}

This leak doesn't make any sense as this is an internal alloc to
std::vector for resizing itself.  And this is a single vector instance
allocated on the stack:

  std::vector<FilePath> subpaths;
  ...
    subpaths.push_back(path);

and so its destructor should be called at function exit, which should free
all of its internal memory.  This should have nothing to do with FilePath
or DomStorageContext or any chromium code.

On chromeos 6 it seems to first show up here:
http://build.chromium.org/p/chromium.memory.fyi/builders/Chromium%20OS%20%28valgrind%29%286%29/builds/12926

But I can't find any suspect commit that clearly triggered this.

I'm going to suppress it to get the bots green.", '']

['Issue 199641: Implement the API provided by u-boot and exported to vboot_reference', 'This bug is to implement all VbEx-prefix APIs on u-boot.', '']

['Issue 216661: shill: Provide an api function to get a service matching given properties without modifying it.', "Currently the shill's Manager API provides GetService(dict properties) / ConfigureService(dict properties).
This function does three things:
- Search for a Service matching the given properties. The exact set of properties that is compared depends on the network type and is Shill's internal choice.
- If no matching network is found, creates a new one.
- The found or new network is configured with the provided properties.

In order to improve the implementation of network settings on Chrome's side, it would help to clearly separate these functionalities (crbug.com/148353).

We could provide in the Manager API:
  object GetService(dict properties):
    returns the path of a matching Service.
  object CreateService(dict properties):
    creates a new Service with the given properties.
    If another Service matching the given properties
    exists already, no Service is created but an error
    returned.

in the Service API:
  void Configure(dict properties):
    configures this Service with the given properties
    (is the same as repeatedly calling SetProperty).


Properties that are used in the matching of Services
should not be modifiable, otherwise we may end up with
several Services matching given properties. However this
can still happen, if not all relevant properties are provided.
As the shill API does not mentioned which properties these
are, this case is very likely to happen.", '']

['Issue 234215: Recover ARM-optimized atomicops.h internal header for Android', 'A recent patch [1] removed the ARM-specific inline optimizations that were in base/atomicops_internal_gcc_arm.h and forces all ARM-based builds to use pure GCC sync intrinsics instead [2]

Unfortunately, this is a slight performance regression for Android. Experience shows that these result in function calls that are 2 to 3 times slower than custom inlined assembly operations.

This bug is to track that atomicops_internal_gcc_arm.h should be reinstantiated for Android/ARM.

Here are typical numbers I collected a long time ago comparing various implementations of the "atomic_inc" function with full barriers:

                                 ldrex/strex     kernel-helper   gcc-builtins   mutex
*    HTC Dream / stock Android         n/a           94 ns          157 ns      472 ns
*    HTC Dream / CyanogenMOD           n/a           68 ns           89 ns      342 ns
*    HTC Magic                         n/a           92 ns          120 ns      472 ns
*    Morotola Droid (original)       15 ns           24 ns           43 ns      369 ns
*    Google Nexus One                15 ns           26 ns           37 ns      140 ns
*    Google Nexus S                  10 ns           15 ns           26 ns       82 ns
*    Morotola Xoom                   34 ns           67 ns           69 ns      121 ns
*    Galaxy Nexus                    28 ns           49 ns           55 ns       91 ns
*


[1] https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10831358
[2] http://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc-4.6.4/gcc/Atomic-Builtins.html', '']

['Issue 248427: Extension API for adding third party file systems (chrome.fileSystemProvider)', "After some discussion and investigation, Extension API seems to be a more promising approach than Pepper (issue 240629). I'm gong to get something to work, to see if this approach will fly, or not.", '']

['Issue 267639: Add permission warning for declarativeWebRequest', 'Based on an API review by the extensions team, for security reasons, the currently existing "declarativeWebRequest" permission should be associated with a warning string about the extension being able to "block parts of web pages".

Also, the declarativeWebRequest permissions needs to be treated as less powerfull than <all_urls> host permission, i.e., if an extension dropped <all_urls> or equivalent host permissions, and added declarativeWebRequest, no permission warning should be displayed (the user already agreed to the extension having access to data on all sites).

This bug tracks adding this permission.', '']

['Issue 270033: Improve error messages for generic DOM exceptions.', 'For example, rather than "SecurityError: An attempt was made to break through the security policy of the user agent.", we might say "SecurityError: \'document.domain\' assignment failed: \'ample.com\' is not a suffix of \'example.com\'."\n\nThis is just a metabug to wrap up all the (hundreds) of callsites that we\'ll want to look at.', '']

['Issue 270918: BrowserTests renderer uses legacy software mode or OSMesa instead of compositing with TestContexts', "The GPU process is not used by the browser compositor when we use test contexts,
but it is still launched, and it is used by the Renderer compositor. This is a
super total waste of CPU cycles.

Switching tests to using OSMesa with test compositor has no effect in the
browser, but changes the timing with the renderer compositor starting up/running
etc. Since the bots don't have real GL, the renderer compositor just fails to
create an OutputSurface, and I think falls back into legacy software path.

This legacy path is, as the name suggests, going to go away. So this means I
guess we need to make browser tests not need it to run. We should make the
renderer compositor use test contexts which are super fast, when the browser is
using test contexts. This is blocked on the fact that the code uses
WGC3DCommandBufferImpl::SetLatencyInfo(). This same function is used in the
BrowserCompositorOutputSurface and prevents us from using test contexts there
for unit tests.


This for sure affects aura platforms.

On other platforms, we don't have a browser compositor, but we should use test contexts in the renderer still instead of falling into software mode, or instead of OSMesa which is slow, unless you want real output for which there should command line flags (right now we have --disable-test-compositor for the browser compositor in aura).", '']

['Issue 272416: DevTools: support asynchronous call stacks', "It'd be hugely valuable to work back to the source of an asynchronous event.

Use cases:
* Long-running timers
* XHRs
* Promises

I imagine we could cull the call stack if the nesting depth is beyond a threshold (like 4).", '']

['Issue 287823: Proposal: Add a redraw callback for 2D canvas', 'Motivation: Browsers tend to suffer from bloated memory consumption when multiple tabs are open. 2D Canvas elements are particularly bad because they are currently forced to retain the contents of their pixel buffers.  With a redraw callback, the browser would be able to evict canvas backing stores in low-memory conditions, and redraw the contents when needed. Evicting the contents of canvases that are not currently visible on-screen could be achieved with little impact on user experience, and would help maintain good global RAM hygiene, which is especially important on mobile platforms.

Proposal:
The redraw call back could be exposed in several ways:

Option 1: dictionnary arg to getContext:
canvas.getContext("2d", {redrawCallback: myRedrawCallback});

Option 2: event listener on the canvas element, much like webgl's context loss handling:
canvas.addEventListener('redraw', myRedrawCallback, false);


Option 2 is consistent with similar existing WebGL APIs for handling context level events. On the other hand, option 1 forces the callback to be defined at context creation time.  The reason that matters is that on platforms that have less reliable graphics subsystems/drivers, we disable gpu-accelerated canvas rendering to avoid data loss in the event of a graphics context loss.  If the redraw callback is set, it would be possible to accelerate 2d canvas contexts on such platforms without fear of losing data.  The decision of whether or not to use gpu-acceleration must be made at context creation time.', '']

['Issue 320200: content::RenderViewImpl::media_stream_client_ leak', 'RenderViewImpl::media_stream_client_ is created in InitializeMediaStreamClient(), as an instance of MediaStreamImpl.  It proceeds to hold this in media_stream_client_ and web_user_media_client_, both unscoped pointers, and never destroys them

Regardless of whether this might conceivably be by design or not: the MediaStreamImpl takes as an argument content::RenderThreadImpl::current()->GetMediaStreamDependencyFactory() as an unscoped pointer and assume that the MediaStreamDependencyFactory outlives itself.  This is a problem since the MediaStreamDependencyFactory is destroyed on destruction of the RenderThreadImpl, but the MediaStreamImpl is itself never destroyed.  This manifests itself as the stack trace at bottom, when running WebrtcBrowserTest.GetVideoStreamAndStop

The ownership hierarchy is:

ScopedVector<UserMediaRequestInfo> MediaStreamImpl::user_media_requests_
-> blink::WebMediaStream UserMediaRequestInfo::web_stream
--> MediaStreamExtraData (indirectly) WebMediaStream::m_private
---> scoped_refptr<webrtc::VideoSource> 
----> cricket::ChannelManager* VideoSource::channel_manager_ (note: unscoped)

scoped_ptr<MediaStreamDependencyFactory> RenderThreadImpl::media_stream_factory_
-> scoped_refptr<webrtc::PeerConnectionFactory> MediaStreamDependencyFactory::pc_Factory_
--> scoped_refptr<cricket::ChannelManager> PeerConnectionFactory::channel_manager_

Note that the channel_manager_ pointer of the first hierarchy points (unowned) at the channel_manager_ scoped_refptr of the second hierarchy (owned), but the first outlives the second.

['Issue 324025: ChromeOS 3.10 tracing CLOCK_SYSTEM_TRACE conflicts with CLOCK_TAI', "Previous ChromeOS kernels extended the clock_gettime interface to expose the clock used for trace events to Chrome, but as of Linux 3.10 the ABI extension has a conflict and can no longer be used.

We need to revert out (should have been dropped) the old change which adds CLOCK_SYSTEM_TRACE and come up with a different solution which is either upstream or at least can be carried alongside upstream without conflicts.

There is a *lot* of upstream discussion about this type of function, see this thread:
https://lkml.org/lkml/2012/10/16/173

Based on that and some private discussion I'm going to try to solve this by implementing a dynamic clock source, which will result in a device file being created which can be used for the trace clock timestamps.

There will also need to be a change to Chrome which looks for this device and uses it if it's present.  

Obviously getting this upstream would be very handy.", '']

["Issue 352347: Don't autofill passwords where confirmation is required", "UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/34.0.1847.60 Safari/537.36

Example URL:

Steps to reproduce the problem:

['Issue 365434: Hardware Accelerated Decode: Seeking near the end of a some variable framerate videos never completes', "UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/33.0.1750.152 Safari/537.36

Example URL:
http://browserbugs.vidmaker.net/windows_ha_seeking/

Steps to reproduce the problem:
Seek to frames in the last GOP of some variable frame rate media.

What is the expected behavior?
Video tag should display the frame that corresponds to the seek time.

What went wrong?
Playback hangs; video tag stops responding.

Did this work before? N/A 

Is it a problem with Flash or HTML5? HTML5

Does this work in other browsers? Yes 

Chrome version: 34  Channel: stable
OS Version: 7
Flash Version: 

  We are seeing seeking issues with variable framerate H.264 media when Hardware Accelerated Video Decode is enabled. Issue appears with both nVidia and AMD GPUs. Seeking in other applications that use DXVA2 do not exhibit this behavior. Issue goes away when hardware accelerated decode is disabled.

  Certain variable framerate videos are not able to seek to the last GOP of the video, and attempting to seek there puts the player into a bad state after which any seeking or playback is no longer possible. Other variable framerate videos don't fail completely but exhibit other poor behavior such as seeking to the wrong frames in the last GOP.", '']

['Issue 369661: Remove page id', 'As a first step towards tracking subframe session history in the browser process (issue 369654) for out-of-process iframes (issue 99379), we will need to make the browser process responsible for allocating page IDs.  Today the renderer allocates them as identifiers for joint session history items (i.e., stops in the back/forward chain).  As frames are farmed out across multiple processes, the browser process will need to allocate them instead.', '']

['Issue 369989: HQP Should Be More Aggressive with Few Visits', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/34.0.1847.132 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. I visited this url: http://developer.android.com/reference/android/os/Bundle.html
2. I write "bundle" in the omnibox 
3. I write "android bundle" in the omnibox

What is the expected behavior?
In both cases, that url should appear; in my case most probably as the first choice as I don't think I ever visited any other url with the word "bundle" in it; anyway surely before searches for the word "bundle"

What went wrong?
With "android bundle" it behaves as expected (proving that the url _is_ in the history).

With just "bundle", the omnibox only proposes a handful of searches, most of them stupid.

Oh, now that I have tried again (after having visited the url again), it does show the url as the third choice.
Two things are wrong:
- having visited the url just ONCE should be enough to have it appear, if there aren't other urls to compete with. Matching urls in the history should ALWAYS have priority over searches, no matter what.
- when it does appear it should be the first option (again, that a search has priority over an url that matches is stupid)

Did this work before? N/A 

Chrome version: 34.0.1847.132  Channel: stable
OS Version: 
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 13.0 r0', '']

['Issue 372436: Limit Service Worker event execution time', "We should kill/stop the worker if JavaScript runs too long. The goal is to prevent it from hogging the CPU and also to preserve battery power on mobile.

Q: Is it enough to limit the wall-clock time that the SW is alive after the event fires, or do you see a strong reason to try to bound cpu
time too?
A: I think wall-clock time should be roughly the same. If the SW is not getting scheduled, there is a bigger problem altogether, either with the page or with our implementation.

Q: Would you expect to want to pass different time limits in from the source of the Push API event, or would a generic limit on all SW
events be enough?
A: A generic limit seems sufficient.

Kinuko: I'm initially assigning to you, but please reassign as appropriate.", '']

['Issue 374592: chrome.storage.local.get unreasonably slow', "UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/34.0.1847.137 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:
I ran the following snippet in a content script. I made sure that my extension is the only one enabled in Chrome at the time:

chrome.storage.local.set({'testValue': [1,2,3]}, function() {
    var start = new Date().getTime()
    chrome.storage.local.get({'testValue': []}, function(data) {
        console.info('Retrieval took ' + (new Date().getTime() - start) + 'ms')
    })
})

What is the expected behavior?

What went wrong?
The above code snippet shows:
Retrieval took 1126ms

I know we're spoiled these days, but over 1 second to access a simple array in local storage seems unreasonable. Is there a known performance issue with chrome.storage.local?

WebStore page: 

Did this work before? N/A 

Chrome version: 34.0.1847.137  Channel: stable
OS Version: 6.3
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 13.0 r0", '']

['Issue 377191: Linux scroll bars pop back to starting position when mouse moves to the side', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/35.0.1916.114 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. Go to web page large enough to need scroll bars
2. Grip scroll bar, and scroll to bottom
3. While still holding mouse button down, slide mouse sideways

What is the expected behavior?
Scroll bar should remain where it is as mouse slides sideways

What went wrong?
Scroll bar snaps back to where it was before you began scrolling

Did this work before? Yes Previous version

Chrome version: 35.0.1916.114  Channel: stable
OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 13.0 r0

This was added intentionally. Issue 337919 was the discussion of the code that was added; this behavior is standard on Windows, but on Linux it is not standard and is very disturbing when you are not used to it.', '']

['Issue 382126: Chrome gets stuck in full screen mode after watching full screen video', "UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/36.0.1985.49 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1.Install chrome (latest stable or beta) under linux/gnome/cinnamon.
2.Visit any page that uses full screen/watch video in full screen.
3.Exit full screen mode using esc for videos, or using the full screen toggle hotkey in cinnamon.

What is the expected behavior?

What went wrong?
While esc will unmaximize a video as expected, the chrome window remains stuck in fullscreen mode and the toggle fullscreen hotkey does not function properly. As tabs are hidden in FS mode this is very annoying.

If you toggle-maximize and then toggle-fullscreen chrome will usually relinquish the fullscreen and drop into an unmaximized window, however after experiencing issues with Pepperflash and quitting and restarting chrome, now all windows (including control+n new windows) are locked in full screen mode and nothing I have tried seems to fix it.

Did this work before? Yes google-chrome-stable_33.0.1750.152 (linux-amd64)

Chrome version: 36.0.1985.49  Channel: beta
OS Version: gentoo
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 14.0 r0

I don't know when this broke since I didn't update for a while.", '']

['Issue 383224: webkitRequestFilesystem hangs indefinitely due to corrupted Filesystem', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_9_3) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/35.0.1916.114 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:
It's difficult to get reliable reproduction steps, because this problem seems to happen randomly.  But in general, the behavior I am seeing is:

1. I have a Packaged App with the "unlimitedStorage" permission that uses the HTML5 filesystem API via window.webkitRequestFilesystem
2. On startup, the app makes a call to webkitRequestFilesystem, and uses the returned Filesystem object to interact with persistent storage.

What is the expected behavior?
webkitRequestFilesystem should return within a reasonable amount of time, either calling the success or error callback.

What went wrong?
Neither callback is ever called, repeated calls to webkitRequestFilesystem will continue to exhibit this behavior.  Occasionally, after some time (anywhere between 30 minutes and several hours), the callbacks will finally be invoked, and the app will continue to function as usual.

Looking at a log file generated from a Chromebook(attached), it would seem that a lock has been left on one of the files related to managing the sandbox database, and the database manager goes into a loop trying to repair it and failing to (because the file remains locked). 

WebStore page: 

Did this work before? N/A 

Chrome version: 35.0.1916.114  Channel: stable
OS Version: 8.1
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 13.0 r0

This seems to be the easiest to reproduce on Windows and CROS.  Some users have seen it on OSX as well.  
  This is causing a pretty nasty problem with our app, as we use the HTML5 filesystem to cache our content locally, and our app is basically unable to function when we can't even get an error response back. On some machines, closing all chrome processes solves the problem.  This isn't easy for end users that have the background option enabled (on by default?), and aren't aware that closing all browser windows doesn't actually do the trick.', '']

['Issue 402136: Resource request message swamped browser IO thread in telemetry smoothness test on wordpress', 'This is the trace from running telemetry smoothness test on wordpress

tools/perf/run_benchmark --browser=android-chrome-shell smoothness.key_mobile_sites --page-filter=wordpress --profiler=trace

At around 4075ms, a lot of ResourceHostMsg_RequestResource message coming
from renderer swamped browser IO thread, delayed the renderer swap buffer message, and pushed the browser compositor into high latency mode.', '']

['Issue 406487: Memory leaks in gin and/or mojo when running SerialApiTest.Connect', 'See log spew that follows. I don't know if this the result of a bad test, that gin is leaking, or that mojo+gin are leaking. Adam mentioned a while back we don't necessarily clean things up when shutting down v8 (356785). ['Issue 410050: Empty policy files should not prevent Chromoting host start-up', "When loading policy files, the Chromoting host will refuse to start if any cannot be parsed. This makes sense if the file has some contents because it's an indication that the user has attempted to lock it down, but failed. In this case, the safe approach is to fail to start up. However, an empty file should be treated as if it weren't there.", '']

['Issue 410958: DevTools: Have Chrome flag to automatically open developer tools in new tabs', "Version: 37.0.2062.94 (Official Build 290621) 
OS: Mac OS X 10.9.4

This is a feature request to have a Chrome flag to make the developer tools open on every new tab (and maybe automatically break before the first line of Javascript).

This is useful for developers who want to debug links that open in new pages. Other developers have tried to work around this.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12212504/automatically-open-chrome-developer-tools-when-new-tab-new-window-is-opened
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16210468/chrome-dev-tools-how-to-trace-network-for-a-link-that-opens-a-new-tab
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/google-chrome-developer-tools/HhwKHUryNaA

I'm on the Chrome New Tab Page team and we've been trying to track down a bug relating to a part of our page not loading. A feature like this would help our debugging a ton.", '']

['Issue 412331: Implement and ship Presentation API (presenting context) in Blink', 'Change description:

The goal of the Presentation API is to enable web content to access external presentation-type displays and use them for presenting web content.

Changes to API surface:

* "availablechange" event
* navigator.presentation.startSession()
* navigator.presentation.joinSession()
* navigator.presentation.session (for the presented content only)

Links:

CG: http://www.w3.org/community/webscreens/
Public standards discussion: http://webscreens.github.io/presentation-api/
Changes currently being discussed: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-webscreens/2014Aug/0003.html
Demos: http://www.w3.org/community/webscreens/presentation-api-demos/

Support in other browsers:

Internet Explorer: plans unknown
Firefox: started intent to implement thread at https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/mozilla.dev.webapi/Rjvu-cBJ1TY/r0GeiIbDAIcJ
Safari: plans unknown, some members of the team are members of the community group', '']

['Issue 422978: Create experimental WebGL extension to support input fast pathing in shaders', 'By populating input events further down the pipeline we can reduce latency caused by the the depth of the pipe. 

The extension API will look something like:
    
    SubscribeUniform(GLenum target, const GLchar *name);

    The extension is generic, but will be used for input events initially.

Where target is the uniform the user wishes to subscribe to in their shaders (e.g. gl.MousePosition), and name is the name they wish the uniform to be called (e.g. "uMousePosition").

When a draw command is made the Gpu Service will try to populate all uniforms the user has subscribe to using the name they've provided.

Input events will need to be forwarded to the Gpu Service as quickly as possible to reduce latency further.', '']

['Issue 433760: Texture "shearing" on my Note 4 and Chrome 39 beta Android', "Made this for a client: http://tinyurl.com/n6y3lme

Press the grey outer wheel, then the biggest colored wheel, then the grey one, then the colored one, and so on -- shearing will begin after a few tries... at least it does for me.

Didn't know my Note 4 was such a piece of junk...!!!", '']

['Issue 444744: Content Settings iframe behavior may not be expected', "Version: 40
OS: All

Currently, granting a content setting (e.g. Location) inside an iframe only grants it for that exact parent/child frame combination. Viewing the same iframe on another site prompts again, and visiting the iframe origin directly prompts a 3rd time.

This may not be the behavior users/developers expect, but just a result of the way we've engineered the permissions system. We first need to investigate what other browsers are doing, and decide how we want Chrome to behave in these circumstances.", '']

['Issue 448379: Feature Request: heap snapshot/allocation in console API', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_10_1) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/39.0.2171.95 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:
NA

What is the expected behavior?
It would be useful to record heap snapshots and heap allocations programatically.

Use case - A common workflow for fixing memory leaks:

1. Reload
2. Start recording allocations / take a heap snapshot
3. Execute leaky code
4. Stop recording / take a heap snapshot
5. Analyse profile
6. Repeat

Steps 2-4 currently need user interaction. This has two downsides: Imprecision (it can be difficult to guarantee that the code under investigation is the only user code executed during the profile period) and interruption (open profile panel, select the right type of profile, record, execute code, return to devtools, stop recording. Doing this programmatically would saves time and allow to me to focus on thinking, not clicking).

A possible API to start discussion:

console.snapshot([label])
console.allocation([label])
console.allocationEnd()

These methods are analogous to the UI "record" buttons, following the pattern of the timeline/profile methods.

allocation/allocationEnd are not great method names but they are consistent with the style of the timeline and profile methods. recordHeapAllocations/stopRecordingHeapAllocations are more explicit but unwieldy, and quite incongruous with the console API's terse method names. I am sure there are better names for each of these methods.

If there is interest in this feature and it is feasible, I am interested in contributing the patch.

What went wrong?
NA

Did this work before? N/A 

Chrome version: 39.0.2171.95  Channel: stable
OS Version: OS X 10.10.1
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 16.0 r0', '']

['Issue 463202: Add a metric to measure Omnibox typing responsiveness', "Add a metric to measure UI responsiveness.

Initial metric will measure time it takes between typing a character in the omnibox until the omnibox text is painted. High values of this indicate the browsing not keeping up with the user's typing.

This is what Syzygy team uses (manually) to determine the impact of their instrumentation.

Note: It would also be interesting to measure the time until omnibox suggestion results appear - but this is a different problem and depends on other factors (e.g. network requests) - and thus not simply a measure of browser responsiveness.", '']

['Issue 468955: Add new permissions flow for USB devices supported by a printerProvider app.', "Currently USB API usage requires explicitly noting in the app manifest which device VID+PID pairs it wants access to. This ensures app developers can't fingerprint users' machines. 

This creates a problem for some vendors who've released large numbers of similar products over the past couple of decades - in order to provide a Chrome App for these devices they need to research and enumerate the PIDs from hundreds or thousands of SKUs, which isn't viable.

This FR is to be able to set a filter instead of enumerating, for 
- vendor_id
- interface class
- interface subclass
- interface protocol type 

...either all four, or just the first three. Could reuse the DeviceFilter from the API (https://developer.chrome.com/apps/usb#type-DeviceFilter).

Important: the app shouldn't get access to devices that match the filter or get further information about them (e.g. PID or other finger-printable info), it should only be notified when one is available. This allows it to know when it should request access from the user for available devices it's able to handle.", '']

['Issue 470600: Android notification that Chrome is playing in the background should have controls', 'This is a feature request for UI notification that indicates that Chrome background tab is playing sound.

When a user tap on notification, the UI should appear that can bring the user to the playing tab, but it should also have controls to pause the playing, similar in form and function to how Google Play Music behaves.

Attaching a screenshot of a Google Play Music notification, we might have something similar, but without Back and Forward buttons.

This issue is related to http://crbug.com/414810', '']

["Issue 494210: When Chrome's internal Task Manager is opened, auto scrolling stutters on any page", "UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/45.0.2415.0 Safari/537.36

Example URL:
 http://www.w3schools.com/html/html5_intro.asp

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. Open Chrome's internal Task Manager.
2. Open any URL in a new tab (for example open the HTML5 introduction page).
3. Try to auto scroll the page.
4. Observe the skipped frames that happens periodically.
5. Close the Task Manager.
6. Auto scrolling is smooth with no dropped frames.

What is the expected behavior?
Smooth auto scrolling.

What went wrong?
Auto scrolling is dropping frames while Chrome's internal Task Manager is opened.

Does it occur on multiple sites: Yes

Is it a problem with a plugin? No 

Did this work before? N/A 

Does this work in other browsers? Yes 

Chrome version: 45.0.2415.0  Channel: canary
OS Version: 6.3
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 18.0 r0", '']

['Issue 499331: Android System WebView No Longer Opens Links in Web Browser', 'Steps to reproduce the problem:
Call loadUrl("https://google.com") on a WebView in an Android app. Or, load up some content in a WebView that has links in it, and click on a link.

What is the expected behavior?
The WebView to pop up a Web browser to view the redirected-to URL or the linked-to URL.

What went wrong?
The redirected-to link or the clicked-on link opens up in the WebView itself. This is contrary to the documented behavior of WebView and is contrary to the actual behavior of WebView that we have had for seven years.

Did this work before? Yes 10 minutes ago, before I updated the Android System WebView to 43.0.2357.121

Chrome version:   Channel: stable
OS Version: 5.1
Flash Version:', '']

['Issue 499864: Console: Handle object literals', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/45.0.2424.0 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. Open devtools' console
2. Enter {a: 4, b: 5}
3. Be annoyed by the error.

What is the expected behavior?
The console should give a preview of the object.

What went wrong?
The console sees the leading curly brace as a block scope declaration. That is annoying and a source of confusion - see http://stackoverflow.com/q/17298912

Did this work before? No 

Chrome version: 45.0.2424.0  Channel: canary
OS Version: 
Flash Version: 

The console should be smart enough to understand the user intended to write an object literal and treat the input as such.

There are several ways to go about this:

node/io do this by simply checking if the input is delimited by curly braces (https://github.com/nodejs/io.js/blob/6d95f4ff923018bb9720888e4ea986cddf0ff5b5/lib/repl.js#L294-L299).

While that works for the simple case, with the advent of useful block scoping (via `let`) it's not too future proof. To deal with that, before wrapping in parentheses, I thought of trying something like this: https://gist.github.com/Zirak/d8f40d8101eecba36dea
Just trying to "compile" the code by passing it into `Function`, and if that raises a SyntaxError then trying to "compile" it again with parentheses. Putting that together with io's check gave results so far.

If this looks ok, I have a PR almost ready to implement this.

Thoughts?', '']
