['Issue 556906: Allow chrome extensions to disable/customize the "you have gone full screen" bubble', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/46.0.2490.86 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:

See the following stackoverflow post: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/28434311/can-i-disable-the-youve-gone-full-screen-notification-in-chrome-with-chrome-e. Currently, power users must use an external launcher to disable the bubble. It works, but it's a very hacky, inelegant solution that could be made much better with a little help from the chrome development team.

What is the expected behavior?

Other browsers such as Firefox allow extensions to customize the fullscreen notification. For instance, duration can be controlled with the full-screen-api.warning.timeout preference.

What went wrong?

As mentioned earlier, unlike in Firefox, a custom launcher is necessary to disable the "you have gone full screen" notification. To fix this, either allow extensions to modify the hard-coded constants (kInitialDelayMs, kIdleTimeMs, etc) that control the notification in exclusive_access_bubble.cc via an API or add a flag to disable the bubble altogether (allowing extensions to trivially create their own notification dialog when full screen is entered in place of the built in one).

Did this work before? N/A 

Chrome version: 46.0.2490.86  Channel: stable
OS Version: 6.1 (Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2)
Flash Version: 

I'm willing to code up a patch to implement either the proposed flag or proposed API, so long as the chrome team is willing to apply it (and no other better qualified chrome developer steps up to the task obviously). Otherwise, it seems "power users" that wish to disable the bubble will be forced to continue to use a custom launcher instead of a regular, chrome web store approved extension. The chrome dev team tends to be fairly forward thinking, so perhaps they will recognize the logic in approving a flag/api patch not only because it will make a lot of power users very happy as evinced by the official thread on the matter (https://productforums.google.com/forum/#!topic/chrome/v0CxM5ur-PE), but also to render the development of external, unofficial APIs designed to allow power users to customize the browser in ways "off-putting" to the lcd segment of the user base unnecessary. APIs which can trivially be developed since the browser is open-source and pdb's for the official binaries are publically available (at https://chromium-browser-symsrv.commondatastorage.googleapis.com).', '']

['Issue 562739: Touch&hold right-click behaviour in Chrome differs from everywhere else in the OS in W10', "UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/46.0.2490.86 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. On a windows 10 touch device, try to right-click. 
2. Once the touch-cursor has switched to the square right-click indicator release.
3. Browser mis-registers click as a left-click.

What is the expected behavior?
Once the touch has caused the square indicator to pop up, it should register clicks as a right-click.

What went wrong?
It appears that chrome manages it's long-press right-clicks independently of the OS, so to actually perform a right-click, you have to hold the long-press several hundred milliseconds (I'd guess ~500 ms) *after* the normal right-click hold duration. 

Additionally, the right-click menu opens while the touch is still held, rather then upon the touch-release as it works everywhere else in the OS. This does happen in certain OS contexts, but it's well after a 5+ second hold, rather then the short duration as seen in chrome.

Did this work before? N/A 

Chrome version: 46.0.2490.86  Channel: stable
OS Version: 10.0
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 19.0 r0", '']

['Issue 27739: Clear Specific Saved Form Data, e.g. with right click', 'Feature request: (please tag with this, I do not know how)

Many current browsers (including chrome) provide a function to "remember 
saved form data" including phone numbers, email addresses and other pieces 
of data entered into forms by users. When submitted, these pieces of data 
are remembered by browsers and associated with the title of the input 
field.

This is designed to be (and is) a massive help to users when filling out 
form information. Saving time and perhaps helping a user remember certain 
data (such as a username).


Browsers also provide a function (somewhere) to delete all of this saved 
form information.


In chrome "clear browsing data..." gives users an option to "clear saved 
form information" from different periods of time (last day, last weeks, 
last 4 weeks or all time).


This is needed as users may type sensitive data into a particular form 
which a user does not want a browser to remember. For example online 
banking details in non-password fields. Or credit card details in an online 
shop.


Clearing all saved form data from all time is quite impractical for most 
users (as this defeats the whole point of it remembering users details; 
speed and forgetting usernames etc.)


There are certain situations currently when a user might have to undertake 
this impractical action (of clearing all saved form information).

* If a user forgets to use incognito mode, and:
* If a user enters sensitive form information into a form that they then do 
not return to for some time, and thus do not realise that the data was 
saved.
* If a different (permitted) user enters other data in a form that the 
normal user would like to remove.


Current implementation:
   User would have to remove all saved form data.

Desired implementation:
 *  User has option to remove individual piece of data, perhaps through 
right clicking on the saved form data currently being provided as an option 
by the browser.
 *  User has single unified login to chrome and can log-out, with chrome 
remembering saved form information when logged-in and forgetting any data 
submitted while a user was logged-out. (See Issue 812)

Thank you in advance for reading. Best Regards, Philip B', '']

["Issue 79003: Commit queue can't submit anything that touches extension docs.", "`chrome/common/extensions/PRESUBMIT.py` throws a warning whenever any file inside of `chrome/common/extensions/api` or `chrome/common/extensions/docs` is edited. It doesn't distinguish between cases in which the dependent documentation _is_ actually generated, and cases in which the documentation _hasn't_ been generated.

Since it always throws a warning, and hence always has an error exit code, the commit queue won't process the commit. I'd like for that not to be the case, as it's much safer to commit through the queue... If you've got good ideas about how to make the presubmit check more accurate, I'm happy to do the coding.

maruel, I think you're the right guy for the commit queue, but I've no idea if you're responsible for the presubmit checks. If you're not the right guy, you might know the right guy.  :)", '']

['Issue 88945: Add API for extension to request an update check of itself', "In the past we've occasionally gotten requests from developers to have a way to force an update check of their own extension. Also in some situations if we had this API, we might suggest a developer use it to solve a problem they're running into, such as the problem described in Issue 82145. 

It would probably make sense to have it be:

chrome.extension.requestUpdateCheck(callback);

To avoid DOS attacks we'd probably want to have some reasonable throttling.  

We'd have to think a little about what (if anything) to report in the callback. Some possible information I could imagine:

-Time of next regularly scheduled check.
-Update check was throttled (maybe also tell them the next valid time to check?).
-No update available
-Update was available and we're starting to download it (potentially dangerous though - developers might count on being able to do some cleanup work which may lead to race conditions, because we kill the currently running extension as soon as the updated .crx file is downloaded and unpacked).", '']

['Issue 168442: Security: Non-privileged extensions can monitor browsing activity via chrome.tabs.onUpdated events', 'VULNERABILITY DETAILS
The chrome.tabs.onUpdated event is accessible to Chrome extensions even without the "tabs" permission, and leaks the URLs the user navigates to in the changeInfo.url argument to the event callback.

Much (all?) of the tabs API is accessible to unprivileged extensions, beyond the whitelisted set listed in the documentation (create, update, remove, and onRemoved).  Some functions (e.g., query) run without the tabs permission but return sanitized data, but at least the onUpdated event lacks sanitization and leaks the URL.

VERSION
Chrome Version: tested on both "24.0.1312.45 beta" and SVN 174805
Operating System: Ubuntu 12.04 LTS

REPRODUCTION CASE
An extension which includes the code (running in the background page):
  chrome.tabs.onUpdated.addListener(
      function(tabId, changeInfo, tab) {
        logVisitedURLs(changeInfo.url);
      });
will be notified of URLs visited by the user.

NOTES
It's not clear to me what the intended behavior is.  While the documentation states that only a small set of functions are available without the tabs behavior, the code (for example, the query function and the ExtensionTabUtil::CreateTabValue method in chrome/browser/extensions/extension_tab_util.cc make it look like an attempt was made to broaden the API available to unprivileged extension.  However, extensions::BrowserEventRouter::TabUpdated() is missing any similar type of permission check, and so passes the URL even when the tabs permission is not present.  The onUpdated event should have permissions checks added (and other parts of the API should be audited), or the tabs API exported to extensions should be restricted.  The documentation may need updating too.', '']

['Issue 334134: Session data is cleared when the last normal browser window is closed instead of the last browser window of any type', "UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.2; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/32.0.1700.76 Safari/537.36

Example URL:
http://www.insightful-schmidt.info/chrome_session_cookie_bug.php

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. Serve the attached PHP script somewhere. I serve it on my localhost using Apache (it might not work with other configs; it's a quick hack!). I have temporarily uploaded it to http://www.insightful-schmidt.info/chrome_session_cookie_bug.php to ease reproduction.

2. Open Chrome.

3. Visit the URL where the script is served (e.g. http://www.insightful-schmidt.info/chrome_session_cookie_bug.php). Note that the page reports that it is setting a new session cookie.

4. Click the New Window button. A new window will open, and the old window will close. Note that the page reports that the session cookie is already set.

5. Click the Reload button. Note that the page reports that the session cookie is not set (and sets a new one).

What is the expected behavior?
The session cookie should be retained until the entire browser is closed.

What went wrong?
Chrome seems to discard session cookies when what used to be the last browser window is closed, even though a new window has been opened by Javascript in the meantime. Note that the new window is loaded while the cookie is still alive (it is sent to the window's initial URL), but it is discarded after the page load (presumably when the old window is closed, or when the Javascript triggered by the button terminates), so that when another page is loaded in the new window, the session cookie has gone.

Does it occur on multiple sites: Yes

Is it a problem with a plugin? No 

Did this work before? Yes 32.0.1700.68

Does this work in other browsers? Yes 

Chrome version: 32.0.1700.76  Channel: beta
OS Version: 6.2 (Windows 8)
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 12.0 r0

You can work around the bug by instead of just opening chrome at step 2 above, opening chrome and then immediately creating a new tab. Then, at step 5, the session cookie will still exist (and the old window will not be completely closed, but only the tab you loaded the script in).

32.0.1700.72 also has the buggy behaviour--I discovered the bug because I received that version on stable channel even though blog only reported it as released to beta. This affected a number of clients of the company I work for.", '']

['Issue 27526: Make popups closeable.', 'A frequent complaint with browser actions is that developers want to 
programmatically control whether the popup will show on click or not.

Currently the only way to do this is to let it open, then immediately close 
it. This results in a flicker though.

We should either delay painting the popup until after window.onload (and 
not paint it if it has been closed), or else add a new API that allows 
developers to control this.

One way that Erik and I brainstormed is to have a default_popup property in 
the manifest and setPopup() methods, similar to what we have for other 
attributes of browser and page actions.

This would allow the developer to initially not have a popup, but to modify 
it at runtime.', '']

['Issue 385669: Support NaCl in MSan builds', "Currently when running browser_tests under MSan, I see a few NaCl-related reports such as this:

==3== WARNING: MemorySanitizer: use-of-uninitialized-value
    #0 0x7f2e9c783ab9 in NaClSysFutexWake native_client/src/trusted/service_runtime/sys_futex.c:131:0
    #1 0x7f2e9c776ee3 in NaClSysFutexWakeDecoder /mnt/ssd/chromium/src/out_goma_msan/Release/obj/native_client/src/trusted/service_runtime/sel.gen/nacl_syscall_handlers.c:1984:0
    #2 0x7f2e9c8ea880 in NaClSyscallCSegHook native_client/src/trusted/service_runtime/nacl_syscall_hook.c:149:0
    #3 0x7f2e9c84badf in ?? native_client/src/trusted/service_runtime/arch/x86_64/nacl_syscall_64.S:185:0

Uninitialized value was created by an allocation of 'out_buf.i' in the stack frame of function 'NaClSysClockGetTime'
    #0 0x7f2e9c754a20 in NaClSysClockGetTime native_client/src/trusted/service_runtime/nacl_syscall_common.c:1044:0

Since we don't instrument untrusted code, user memory may be poisoned (marked as uninitialized) despite actually being initialized. Then when we try to access it from trusted code (which is instrumented), we get spurious MSan reports.

It would appear that all access to user memory from trusted code goes through the functions defined in native_client/src/trusted/service_runtime/nacl_copy.c, in which case it is trivially easy to get around this issue by adding an MSan annotations to each of those functions. Bennet, could you please confirm whether this is the case?", '']

['Issue 490545: [App Install] Allow beforeinstallprompt event to be redispatched', 'https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=460945 implements the beforeinstallprompt event. This is currently fired outside of web developer control. Ideally, developers would be able to pause the event, and retrigger it later on with their own context.

Proposed syntax is at https://github.com/slightlyoff/AppInstallImprovements/blob/master/explainer.md#controlling-installation

Need to work out how to wire up window.dispatchEvent(e) (where e is a beforeinstallprompt event) to redispatch the event and restart the display pipeline.', '']

["Issue 100028: Chrome Sync doesn't work on Windows 7 64bit", 'ENVIRONMENT
Chrome 14.0.835.202
Windows 7 Professional 64-bit SP1

REPRO STEPS
Scenario 1
1. launch chrome 
2. click on "Set up sync..." in Options\Personal Stuff
3. enter login and password in pop up window
4. Chrome just refreshing the window, no error message

Scenario 2
1. launch chrome

['Issue 100073: Chrome does not honor "bypass proxy server for local addresses"', 'Chrome Version       : 14.0.835.202

What steps will reproduce the problem?

['Issue 100087: Aura: Cursor tracking', 'We need to track cursor position at the desktop level, instead of relying on Windows/X. When we are run in windowed mode on the host environment, reading the cursor may produce a position out of the bounds of the desktop window, so it makes sense to constrain this to motions within the desktop.', '']

['Issue 100088: Aura: Window transience', "There are various cases where we would like transient windows not to be children of their parent. We should add support for transient windows to aura::Window.\n\nIn addition, it may be desirable to have the ability for some of the transient windows' properties to be optionally inherited from the transient parent (bounds, transform, opacity). This part is probably P2 to begin with.", '']

['Issue 100764: Chrome freezes tab / loads in vain when redirected to an unhandled custom URL protocol', "Chrome Version       : 14.0.835.202 (Official Build 103287) m
URLs (if applicable) :
Other browsers tested:
Add OK or FAIL after other browsers where you have tested this issue:
     Safari 5: OK
  Firefox 4.x: OK
IE 7/8/9:

What steps will reproduce the problem?
1. Go on a web page that redirects (HTTP 30x) to an unregistered custom URL protocol (such as ponies://something)
2. Wait as the page is 'loading'
3. Fire up Chrome Dev Tools, see nothing of interest

What is the expected result?

Some kind of message notifying the user that there is no URL handler for this protocol (Firefox does that with a popup - irritating but informative)

What happens instead?

Browser tabs seems to freeze, or attempts to load something indefinitely instead of just admitting it has no way of handling the protocol.

Also, I would expect Web Developers tool to show info about the redirect (and the HTTP request in general), but mabe that's too much to ask!", '']

['Issue 100811: Get improved tab placement on Chrome!', 'Chrome Version       : 7.1.249.1064 (Official Build 45376)

['Issue 100913: Redirect Link Is Confusing', 'The redirect link that shows on the OAuth page is confusing.  Currently it says, "Clicking "Allow access" will redirect you to: https://talkgadget.google.com/talkgadget/blank."

['Issue 142518: ConvertYUVToRGB32Row_{SSE,MMX,C} need to be updated to match platform skia layout', "webkit/media/skcanvas_video_renderer.cc:ConvertVideoFrameToBitmap() sets a config of ARGB_8888, and then the ConvertYUVToRGB32Row_{SSE,MMX,C} paint into the bitmap pixels ordered as ARGB, but this is not how skia works.  Per http://crbug.com/138930#c16 the ARGB_8888 doesn't guarantee ordering, and in fact the real layout is governed by the SkColorPriv.h, e.g. SK_A32_SHIFT.\n\nVerifying correctness here is likely going to require an alternative-layout setup, such as android, to be brought to the point of rendering webkit/media frames.", '']

['Issue 89687: Allow optional bypass of the NTP UI after app install from the web store', "It'd be nice to experiment with a second install flow to allow the store to bypass the launch of the NTP after install.   We'd need some UI to educate users about where the app launcher is located, and we'd need to measure whether this flow performs better than the current NTP flow.", '']

['Issue 355430: ssh: host key verification failed', "Version: 5657.0.2014_03_20_0922 (Test Build - grundler) developer-build leon
OS: ChromeOS

What steps will reproduce the problem?

1.  run reload_asix. Or anything that does lots of SSH to the machine?
2.  eventually fails with:
RELOAD 7024  20140322134153  LINK 1000_full (3 sec)  IP 192.168.1.100 (3 Sec)
RELOAD 7025  20140322134205  LINK 1000_full (3 sec)  IP 192.168.1.100 (1 Sec)
RELOAD 7026  @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@
@    WARNING: REMOTE HOST IDENTIFICATION HAS CHANGED!     @
@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@
IT IS POSSIBLE THAT SOMEONE IS DOING SOMETHING NASTY!
Someone could be eavesdropping on you right now (man-in-the-middle attack)!
It is also possible that a host key has just been changed.
The fingerprint for the RSA key sent by the remote host is
7b:ea:71:30:e9:d8:c5:49:d8:3f:46:e0:5a:42:05:cd.
Please contact your system administrator.
Add correct host key in /home/grundler/.ssh/known_hosts to get rid of this message.
Offending RSA key in /home/grundler/.ssh/known_hosts:65
RSA host key for 192.168.1.100 has changed and you have requested strict checking.
Host key verification failed.


What is the expected output? What do you see instead?
I don't expect the host key to change unless the system is re-installed.
I verified my .ssh/knownhosts file didn't change:

(cr) ((c97f454...)) grundler@firesword ~/trunk/src/scripts $ ls -l /home/grundler/.ssh/known_hosts
-rw-r--r-- 1 grundler eng 26093 Mar  3 14:06 /home/grundler/.ssh/known_hosts
$ date
Sun Mar 23 17:41:51 PDT 2014

I verified the DUT (192.168.1.100) did NOT reboot.
I don't believe this problem is specific to leon. I've seen this before once or two recently but wasn't as sure something else didn't mess with the keys. Now I'm pretty sure something on the DUT changed the SSH host key.", '']

['Issue 414808: Use swarming on main waterfall', "This is a tracking bug for using swarming on the main waterfall.

We have been using swarming on trybots for two months now, with great results. Let's start rolling it out, gradually like we did with trybots, on the main waterfall. Aside from the fast cycle times, this will also also reduce the number of columns.

Tasks that need to be done:
-swarming stability: bug 413005 and bug 401124. these should be live in the next day or two
-switch isolate files to use ninja information, since right now they don't work with debug (component) builds
  -as maruel mentioned over IM, GPU bots already use this so we're almost there
-need the ability to specify different sharding value per builder (i.e. debug Windows is ~5x slower than release because of all the extra asserts that catch bugs. so we might want 5 shards for release bots like we have on trybots, but 25 for debug). we'll need this ability for asan trybots as well.", '']

['Issue 397959: echoCancelation/echoCancellation cannot be used as a mandatory constraint', 'UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_9_4) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/37.0.2062.20 Safari/537.36

Example URL:

Steps to reproduce the problem:

Using a professional sound calibrator (see http://www.bksv.com/products/transducers/acoustic/calibrators/4231) that outputs a stable 94.0 dB SPL at 1000Hz and a professional measurement microphone fully calibrated, we now measure un unstable volume (see waveform in first attachement). ['Issue 438651: RenderFrameHost pointer comparison in tests might be the origin of some flakyness', "I found flakyness in a test I authored and I think it's a problem we might have in other tests as well.

I was relying on a RenderFrameHost pointer comparison between one instance that was already destroyed and a newly created one. Their addresses are normally different but in this case they were not (when running on Windows Release). It seems the new instance simply replaced the exact same memory position as the previous one and so the EXPECT_NE failed.

My changes are in the context of PlzNavigate (browser-side navigation) and made so that the destruction of the previous RFH instance happens before the creation of the new one.

But even while they are inactive, as the swapped out state of RFH is supposed to be eliminated soon this kind of flakyness might being to happen even before PlzNavigate is enabled for good. For instance in navigator_impl_unittest.cc, test RedirectCrossSite, there is a similar comparison that might be affected.

I also note that there might be other tests not necessarily related to RenderFrameHost instances that suffer from the same error pattern.", '']

['Issue 169251: x86 devices: build some parts without PIC (position independent code)', 'A dynamic library compiled _without_ PIC support would be correctly relocated on x86 (32bit only), and would work faster. But there is a certain memory overhead associated with that, also the relocation process negatively affects startup time.

We are generally not in favor of disabling PIC on any platform.
 
Reports from Intel performance guys (that I did not personally reproduce) suggest that we can disable PIC partially only in V8. In this case we should be getting speedups on javascript benchmarks:

sunspider -- 8%
octane -- 5%
(the javascript managed code is not affected by the change, the difference is coming from v8 native layer)

The private memory overhead is additional 2.4MB for the browser process (adds to current 31.5MB) and 0.9MB overhead for each renderer process (adds to current 20MB).

To me the overhead is a bit too large for Android, but I want to hear opinions from other Chrome team members first.', '']

["Issue 464959: Let's reduce the ext4 commit interval, 600 seconds is just too large.", "The 600 seconds commit interval is causing troubles again (issue 364087) and again (issue 373001) and again (issue 423662).

While it may be argued that these issues (together with countless others that haven't been reported or have not been recognized as file corruption issues) should be fixed by adding atomic writes in all the right places, this approach seems cumbersome to the extent of bordering on unfeasible.  

From offline discussion with gwendal@ and sonnyrao@:  The main motivation for choosing a long commit interval is to conserve power.  This is especially true for spinning disks.  Chrome OS used to enable laptop mode but it turned out that this often prevented disks from spinning down in the Chrome OS environment which writes to log files almost constantly.  In the interest of uniformity between battery and A/C operation, in May 2011 the commit interval was fixed to 600 seconds across all operating modes (cf. issue 198668).  However, with the advent of Chromeboxes that don't have a battery, this approach has become untenable.

Therefore, we should
1) Set the commit time interval to the kernel default for devices without battery.
2) Set the commit time interval to the kernel default for devices on A/C power.
3) Set the commit time interval to a trade off between power savings and data preservation for devices on battery power.

1) and 2) are immediately actionable, 3) requires investigation of how quickly after wakeup disk/ssd/emmc power down again.

Notes:
* The above refers to the ext4 commit interval as pars pro toto, virtual memory dirty page expiration parameters may need to be changed accordingly.
* Flash memory wear seems to be a minor concern because modern drives tolerate many hundred cycles (i.e. writing the full capacity of the device many hundred times) and also because the total increase of I/O operations is not exorbitant.", '']

['Issue 458347: Windows heap should be configured to hold on to more memory', 'With the default heap configuration on some machines (Windows 8? Lots of cores?) the Windows heap will aggressively free blocks of memory larger than 16 KB. This can harm performance. For blocks between 16-KB and 512 KB the heap *may* free the memory, or may retain it for later use, which makes for unpredictable performance in tests such as ipc_perftests.

Therefore we should configure the Windows heap to hold on to more memory without decommitting. This will improve performance with a modest memory cost and will reduce unpredictability.

- For allocations below 16 KB the Windows heap uses the LFH -- low-fragmentation-heap -- which is a set of lock-free lists of available memory. This makes small allocations extremely cheap -- comparable to the default heap on Linux.
- Above 512 KB the Windows heap falls back to VirtualAlloc. The total cost for allocating/using/freeing is a bit more than double that of Linux (some of the cost is hidden in the system process).

The problem is in the middle range, from 16-KB to 512-KB. Depending on unknown factors (allocation history, OS? core-count?, who-knows?) these allocations can either be LFH-fast or VirtualAlloc slow. This makes perf-test results highly variable and fundamentally unpredictable, and could be a perf-regression for Chrome.

cpu@chromium.org pointed me to a configuration variable that governs how much memory the Windows heap will hold onto without decomitting -- DeCommitTotalFreeThreshold. This can make the medium-sized allocations go LFH-fast, with a modest/configurable memory overhead.

To set DeCommitTotalFreeThreshold you create a global variable called _load_config_used which is a truncated (0x48 bytes for 32 bits, 0x70 bytes for 64 bits) version of IMAGE_LOAD_CONFIG_DIRECTORY. A few fields must be filled in and DeCommitTotalFreeThreshold can be set to a value such as 1500000 which tells the heap to hold on to up to 1.5 MB memory before decommitting, thus increasing the odds that medium-sized allocations can be satisfied without going to VirtualAlloc.

The _load_config_used structure is used by the Windows loader, as documented here:

http://blog.quarkslab.com/windows-8-ate-my-cookie.html
The Loader uses the ntdll!LdrpFetchAddressOfSecurityCookie function, which relies on RtlImageNtHeaders to locate the IMAGE_NT_HEADERS from the PE, then it gathers the address of IMAGE_LOAD_CONFIG_DIRECTORY{32,64} by using the function RtlImageDirectoryEntryToData with the DirectoryEntry as IMAGE_DIRECTORY_ENTRY_LOAD_CONFIG (10).

The Windows loader finds it because there is a Load Configuration Directory in the PE file for the executable:

dumpbin HeapTest.exe /headers | find "Configuration"
           16860 [      40] RVA [size] of Load Configuration Directory

This has been tested on 32-bit (where it can make a huge difference, up to a 15x speedup) and on 64-bit (where the slowdown has not been seen).

The one risk is that it appears that if the amount is slightly too low then performance can get about 20% worse, for unknown reasons, but probably because all of the blocks are freed simultaneously (removing all benefit) followed by some cache effects which somehow make things slower.', '']

['Issue 351032: Update libpng to version 1.6.17', 'The PNG reference library, used both for encoding and decoding, is currently
at version 1.2, which is very old, but still updated with security fixes.
The current libpng version is 1.6; latest release is 1.6.10.

The main advantage of recent libpng versions is the availability of an
ARM Neon implementation of PNG delta filtering (so far, for decoding only),
which first appeared in version 1.5.

This is a security-sensitive library.

The upgrade work is tracked at https://codereview.chromium.org/190313002/', '']

Mocks will be added to this bug once they have been finalized.', '']

["Issue 124141: System tray icons are scaled on Windows and don't look awesome.", "Chrome system tray icons are scaled on Windows because we provide a single icon size which is not really one-size-fits all.

The correct solution would be to generate an HICON which contains a bunch of different resolutions. When I last looked at icon_utils I didn't see anything that would turn a bunch of SkBitmaps into a multi-resolution HICON, but this might exist - if not, we'd need to write it, then change background_mode_manager.cc to pass multiple SkBitmaps in when it creates the status tray icon.

I'm not actively looking at this, but keeping it on my plate for now anyway.

It's *possible* that fixing this might fix bug 123959, if that bug is caused by windows having to scale our status tray icon.", '']

['Issue 210801: Kernel startup time increase of about 2.1 seconds', 'Chrome OS Version  :  1957.0.0
Chrome Version     :  N/A
Type of computer   :  any
Network info       :  N/A

What steps will reproduce the problem?
1.  Run platform_BootPerfServer, or similar test
2.  Look at the time required for kernel startup

What is the expected output?
Kernel startup time on Alex/ZGB should be about 1.3 or 1.4
seconds.  On faster CPUs, there should be a slightly smaller
startup time.

What do you see instead?
From build 1956.0.0 to build 1957.0.0, kernel startup time jumped by
about 2.1 seconds.  Below are the numbers for Alex and ZGB:

    x86-zgb-r19-R19-1956.0.0 (on 200 cycles):
     time  s%     dt  s%  event
     1488 13%  +1488 13%  startup

    x86-zgb-r19-R19-1957.0.0 (on 200 cycles):
     time  s%     dt  s%  event
     3512  4%  +3512  4%  startup

    x86-alex-r19-R19-1956.0.0 (on 300 cycles):
     time  s%     dt  s%  event
     1411  3%  +1411  3%  startup

    x86-alex-r19-R19-1957.0.0 (on 300 cycles):
     time  s%     dt  s%  event
     3519  1%  +3519  1%  startup


How frequently does this problem reproduce? (Always, sometimes, hard to
reproduce?)
The problem occurred consistently from build 1957 through build 1959.
No test data are available past build 1959, although it seems likely that
the problem continues to persist.

What is the impact to the user, and is there a workaround? If so, what is
it?
Kernel startup is part of the boot critical path, so the user boot time
is at least 20% longer for all users.

Please provide any additional information below.
The boot time change seems to coincide with the conversion to
the linux 3.2 kernel.  Unfortunately, the lack of subsequent boot
time data makes that hard to confirm immediately.

The problem is almost certainly caused by an incorrectly placed
timed wait.  In particular, multiple platforms with different speed
CPUs all see approximately the same size of change (about 2.1
seconds in all cases).', '']

['Issue 127283: Desktop layout should be saved across sessions', 'Version: 20.0.1130.0 canary
OS: cros 2260.0.0

What steps will reproduce the problem?
1. Make sure "Continue where I left off" is selected in Settings > On Startup
2. Size and position a few windows around the desktop
3. Sign out and sign back in

What is the expected output? What do you see instead?
My window arrangements are part of a session, it's not hard to imagine a use case where the user cares very much about the window sizes and positions.

However, upon signing in all windows seem to be restored to the central position, positions / sizes are forgotten.', '']

['Issue 144683: Add support for transitioning to HAVE_CURRENT_DATA', "Currently the WebMediaPlayerImpl doesn't signal transitions to HAVE_CURRENT_DATA so applications can't detect when the first frame is renderer or when the pipeline underflows. 

The code should be updated to:
1. Transition to HAVE_METADATA at the beginning of a seek.
2. Transition from HAVE_METADATA to HAVE_CURRENT_DATA when the first frame is renderered during preroll.
3. Transition from HAVE_ENOUGH_DATA to HAVE_CURRENT_DATA when the pipeline underflows.
4. Tansition from HAVE_CURRENT_DATA to HAVE_ENOUGH_DATA when the pipeline resumes from an underflow.", '']

['Issue 154823: Need some way to save page as plain HTML / HTML-complete on ChromeOS', "ChromeOS has MHTML 'save page' mode enabled as the only way to save a page.  We're still in the process of enabling this for all platforms (issue 120416).

As long as there are known issues with MHTML(eg. issue 154822, issue 154821), I think we need to have an option somewhere to allow ChromeOS to revert to supporting saving as HTML-only and HTML-complete.  Ideally all options would be available as the file type choice in the dialog, but this may be difficult.  I'd be perfectly fine with just having a flag in about:flags to revert to the previous functionality on ChromeOS.

Without this, scenarios that rely on save as (eg. tracking down certain types of non-deterministic webkit issues like issue 145798) are impossible on ChromeOS.", '']

['Issue 350736: chrome.usb does not include "Serial number string" along with vendorId and productId.', 'Chrome Version       : 33.0.1750.146
URLs (if applicable) : https://developer.chrome.com/apps/usb
OS version: any

I'm creating a chrome app that talks to multiple devices via USB.  The chrome.usb APIs do not return the Serial Number of the device with vendorId and productId in the "Device" object.  Only the unique serial number can be used to reliably distinguish two otherwise identical devices.

Unique serial numbers are required by the USB2 specification and are embedded in all USB2 compliant devices.

The 'Device" structure has a 'device' field that is documented as: "The id of the USB device. It remains unchanged until the device is unplugged."  This precludes any movable laptop from distinguishing two devices reliably.

The Device object should contain "serialNumber" to fix this issue.  Alternatively, maybe Serial Number could be added to the chrome.usb.listInterfaces function, but that doesn't make as much sense as chrome.usb.getDevices or chrome.usb.findDevices.

PS - While doing this it might be nice to add "Manufacturer String" and "Product String" as well.', '']

['Issue 224786: Implement unprefixed EME APIs that match the latest draft (object-oriented version)', "Chromium currently implements v0.1b of the EME Editor's Draft [1].
The latest Editor's Draft [2] includes some significant changes since that version. The most significant change was the move to the use of objects for sessions, etc.

This bug serves as an umbrella for all the related work to bring Chrome's implementation closer to the current Editor's Draft.

[1] https://dvcs.w3.org/hg/html-media/raw-file/eme-v0.1b/encrypted-media/encrypted-media.html
[2] https://dvcs.w3.org/hg/html-media/raw-file/tip/encrypted-media/encrypted-media.html", '']

['Issue 234200: [CSS Grid Layout] Properly support for z-index on grid items', 'Per specification, section 8 "Drawing Order of Grid Items", the z-index controls the drawing order. Also the grid element and grid items should generate stacking contexts\n\nWe should get most of the feature for free with having RenderLayers.', '']

["Issue 323784: chromeos-hid-logitech-3.10 : topic branch doesn't work on xhci systems, eg. falco", "I've just tried a T650 trackpad on Falco running chromeos-3.10 with hid-logitech 3.10 merged in. It seems to be failing. This is similar to a problem we ran into for falco,  chrome-os-partner:22224.

chromeos-3.8 doesn't have this problem. Also it seems like chromeos-3.10 before merging chromeos-hid-logitech-3.10 succeeds, maybe not with full functionality, so hopefully this will be easy to bisect.

Assigning to adlr, but if he's out in the next few weeks, i'll take this on myself.", '']

['Issue 409435: Rebaseline tool submits identical layout test results in different port directories', 'https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=408460#c13\n\nThe png images added in that CL produced by the rebaseline tool all have the same header checksums (the images are identical), and the text files similarly. Layout tests on any port can fallback to default image and text results. The rebaseline tool is unnecessarily increasing the size of the blink repository by placing the identical results in different layouttest port directories.', '']

- rebase locally
- reattempt dcommit

['Issue 425360: AutoTest and hardware lab infrastructure should provide ability to restrict tests run based on board', 'Problem: Certain AutoTest and Telemetry tests will require that the TPM be cleared before and/or after each run, e.g., Enterprise enrollment, device policy. Some older boards, such as Lumpy and earlier, do not support software reset of the TPM and require either manual intervention or the aid of servo to perform a TPM reset.\n\nRequest: Provide a mechanism to restrict certain AutoTests within a suite from running on specific  boards.', '']
